====Year of owner's death====
It is possible that an RMD is required after the death of the owner.
If the owner dies on or after reaching their required beginning date, an RMD must be taken for the year of death. The beneficiary is responsible for withdrawing the RMD as if the owner were still alive. This requirement applies event if the beneficiary is the surviving spouse who elects to treat the account as their own.
If the owner dies before reaching their required beginning date, no RMD is required for the year of death. This is true even if the owner had already reached the age at which RMDs typically begin.
For owners who pass away on or after January 1, 2025, beneficiaries may complete RMDs on the later of the beneficiary’s year-of-death tax return deadline—generally April 15, including extensions—or December 31 of the year following the year of death.<ref>{{Cite web| author=Mike Rahn| date=December 19, 2024| title=RMD Regulations’ Year-of-Death Rules Yield Both Answers and Questions| url=https://thelink.ascensus.com/articles/2024/12/18/rmd-regulations-year-of-death-rules-yield-both-answers-and-questions| website=Ascensus}}</ref> For owners who passed away prior to January 1, 2025, beneficiaries must have completed all remaining RMDs by December 31 of the year of death. This could be difficult if the owner died late in the year. In these cases beneficiaries can request a waiver.<ref name="IRS signals" />
====Required beginning date====
Owners may delay their first RMD until April 1 of the following year, which is called the '''required beginning date'''.<ref name="IRSRBD"/> Delaying the first RMD into the following year means two RMDs will be taken that year, which may unexpectedly move the owner into a higher tax bracket.
==Calculation==
Most retirement account custodians provide RMD calculators that are customized to your individual situation.
If an RMD is required, the amount can depend on: * the calculation method * your age * whether you are married * your spouse's age * whether you are the owner or beneficiary
The IRS updated the life expectancy tables<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/FR-2020-11-12/pdf/2020-24723.pdf |title=Updated Life Expectancy and Distribution Period Tables Used for Purposes of Determining Minimum Required Distributions | publisher=Internal Revenue Service | date=November 12, 2020}}</ref> (Tables I, II, and III) for RMDs calculated for 2022 and beyond. The new tables reflect longer life expectancies and in most cases result in lower RMDs. If you are calculating RMDs for years prior to 2022, use the appropriate year of IRS Publication 590-B.
===Entire Interest: What amount is used to calculate the RMD?===
The ending balance of your account as of December 31 of the previous year, with adjustments, is used to calculate your RMD. This amount is called your ''entire interest''. It is your ending balance, adjusted for any outstanding rollovers, asset transfers, or conversions completed during the prior year that are recharacterized to the current year.
=== Uniform Lifetime ===
If you are: * an unmarried owner * a married owner with a spouse 10 or fewer years younger than you, or * a married owner whose spouse is not the sole beneficiary of their account
you use the [https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b#en_US_2024_publink100090310 Table III (Uniform Lifetime)] to calculate your RMD.
The amount of the RMD is equal to the entire interest in your retirement account as of December 31 of the previous year, divided by the owner's life expectancy factor according to [https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b#en_US_2024_publink100090310 Table III (Uniform Lifetime)]. Calculations for different scenarios are described below.
====Example====
Bill turns 73 in March of 2025. The combined balance of all of his non-inherited traditional, SEP, and SIMPLE IRAs on December 31, 2024 was $882,349. He is married, and his spouse is less than 10 years younger. [https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b#en_US_2024_publink100090310 Table III (Uniform Lifetime)] shows a ''Life expectancy factor'' of '''26.5''' at age 73, and the RMD is calculated as: :RMD = $882,349 / 26.5 = '''$33,296'''
This RMD may be taken as late as April 1, 2026.
=== Joint Life and Last Survivor ===
If you are an owner with a spouse more than 10 years younger than you, and your spouse is the sole beneficiary of your account, you use [https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b#en_US_2024_publink100090290 Table II (Joint and Last Survivor Life Expectancy)] to calculate your RMD.
The amount of the RMD is equal to the entire interest in your retirement account as of December 31 of the previous year, divided by the owner's life expectancy factor according to [https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b#en_US_2024_publink100089977 Table I (Single Life Expectancy)].
===RMDs by beneficiaries===
RMDs for accounts inherited by beneficiaries vary based on the date of death of the owner and the relationship between the owner and the beneficiary. Depending on the situation, one or more of these RMD calculation methods can be used. Use the tables earlier in this page to determine which methods are available.
====Single Life Expectancy====
The single life expectancy method spreads RMD payments over the owner or beneficiary's lifetime, depending on the scenario. The RMD amount is recalculated each year based on the projected remaining lifetime.
The amount of the RMD is equal to the entire interest in the retirement account, divided by the life expectancy factor according to [https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b#en_US_2024_publink100089977 Table I (Single Life Expectancy)].
Because this method reflects increased life expectancy each year the owner or beneficiary lives, it provides lower RMDs than other calculation methods.
====Non-recalculating life expectancy====
The non-recalculating life expectancy<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-prior/p590b--2019.pdf |title = Publication 590-B (2019) Distributions from Individual Retirement Arrangements (IRAs) | publisher=Internal Revenue Service | pages=10}}</ref> method spreads RMD payments over a fixed RMD period starting in the year after the owner's death. The number of years depends on whether the owner died on or after their required beginning date.
Reduce the RMD period by 1 for each year since the year following the owner's death.
This method fixes the remaining life expectancy of the beneficiary at the time of the owner's death, which results in higher RMDs than the single life expectancy method.
=====Example=====
Bob inherits a traditional IRA from his mother Agnes in 2019, which had a value of $100,000 as of December 31, 2019. Agnes was 93 in 2019, which means she died after her required beginning date. In 2020, the year following Agnes' death, Bob is 64. Using [https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b#en_US_2024_publink100089977 Table I (Single Life Expectancy)], Agnes' life expectancy in 2019 was 4.6 and Bob's life expectancy in 2020 is 23.7. Bob's life expectancy is larger, so it will be used for the calculation.
Bob's RMDs from Agnes' IRA start in 2020, the year after her death. Bob's RMD is $100,000 / 23.7 = $4219.41.
At the end of 2020, Agnes' IRA has a value of $106,400. Bob's life expectancy is reduced by 1, to 22.7. Bob's RMD in 2021 is $106400 / 22.7 = $4687.22.
====10-year rule==== The 10-year rule requires the contents of an account to be distributed by December 31 of the year containing the 10th anniversary of the owner's death. Under all circumstances the account must be emptied by the end of year 10.
For traditional accounts, if the owner dies on or after their required beginning date, annual RMDs are required using the longer of the non-recalculating life expectancy of the owner or the beneficiary. If the owner dies prior to their required beginning date, no RMDs are required.
For Roth accounts, no annual RMDs are required.
Some beneficiaries have the option of selecting either the 10-year rule or another calculation option. It is usually best to select the option that spreads the RMDs over the largest number of years. This usually means that the other option is better than the 10-year rule.
====5-year rule==== The 5-year rule requires the contents of an account to be distributed by December 31 of the year containing the 5th anniversary of the owner's death. No annual RMDs are required.
=====Example=====
Alan inherits an IRA account from his uncle Bennett in 2019 as a designated beneficiary. Bennett was 70 when he died, and had not yet reached his required beginning date. Alan plans to work until the end of 2022, and for tax planning purposes wishes to empty the account in 2023 and 2024. Alan elects to take distributions using the 5-year rule on September 1, 2020, and must empty the account by December 31, 2024.
==Details==
RMDs have much in common with any other withdrawal from a tax-advantaged account (for example, withdrawals from a [[Traditional IRA]] with non-deductible basis are pro-rata). However, RMDs have several special properties:
*RMDs cannot be rolled back into tax-advantaged accounts (including by way of a [[Roth conversion]]), although they can be taken in-kind or reinvested in the same or similar investments inside a [[taxable account]]. *Withdrawals of more than the RMD amount in a given year do not carry forward to help satisfy RMDs in future years, although they will reduce the balance on which future RMDs are calculated. *Beneficiaries are exempt from early withdrawal penalties for RMDs. Withdrawals by beneficiaries using the ten-year rule are also exempt from early withdrawal penalties.
===Combining distributions from multiple accounts ===
Under certain circumstances, a distribution from one account can be used to satisfy the RMD from a different account.
*RMDs from accounts you inherited cannot be combined with accounts you own. *For IRAs you own, calculate the RMD separately for each IRA that they own. You can withdraw the total amount from one or more of the IRAs.<ref name="Cornell" /> *Workplace plans (e.g., 401(k)) may not be combined with other workplace plans or IRAs. *Inherited IRA RMDs can only be combined if from the same decedent and subject to the same RMD calculation method (e.g., all 10-year rule). Inherited IRA RMDs from different decedents or with different distribution periods cannot be combined.<ref>{{Cite web|last=DeVany|first=Beverly|date=October 10, 2018|title=Combining Inherited IRAs and their RMDs|url=https://irahelp.com/slottreport/combining-inherited-iras-and-their-rmds/#:~:text=The%20RMDs%20also%20cannot%20be,taken%20separately%20from%20each%20account.|website=IRA Help - Ed Slott}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Investopedia|date=September 3, 2024|title=401(k) Required Minimum Distributions (RMDs): Avoid These 4 Mistakes|url=https://www.investopedia.com/articles/retirement/04/120604.asp#:~:text=How%20Do%20RMDs%20Work%20With,you%20inherited%20from%20multiple%20decedents.|website=Investopedia}}</ref><ref name="Pub590B">{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p590b.pdf| title=Publication 590-B (2024), Distributions from Individual Retirement Arrangements (IRAs)| at=Miscellaneous Rules for Required Minimum Distributions| publisher=IRS}} </ref> *Multiple inherited IRA beneficiaries should split the IRA into separate interests so that each beneficiary can: ** Select a fiduciary of choice for investing the inherited IRA; ** Execute their own individual investment plan and account succession. If an IRA having multiple beneficiaries is not split into separate accounts, the required minimum distribution is based on the life expectancy factor for the oldest beneficiary. *A [[403(b)]] contract owner must calculate the RMD separately for each 403(b) contract that they own, but can take the total amount from one or more of the 403(b) contracts.<ref name="Cornell" />
===RMDs and Roth conversions===
For each calendar year a RMD is required, the RMD must be the first money to leave the account. For example, if you wanted to perform a [[Roth conversion]] from a traditional IRA account in a calendar year that also has a RMD, the RMD must be completed ''before'' you perform a subsequent Roth conversion. If you reverse this sequence, the IRS will consider you to have improperly contributed RMD funds into the Roth account, and you will owe a 6% excise tax on the excess contribution, unless corrected before your tax filing deadline. This twist can cause particular problems for the year you turn your RMD age, since you have until April 1 of the following year to complete the RMD, but cannot perform a Roth conversion until the RMD is completed.<ref>{{Cite web|date=April 4, 2023|title=Publication 590-A (2022), Contributions to Individual Retirement Arrangements (IRAs)|url=https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590a|access-date=May 20, 2023|publisher=IRS|series=Excess Contributions Tax}}</ref><ref group="note">See the article [https://www.irahelp.com/slottreport/age-70-%C2%BD-confusion-retirement-accounts Age 70½ Confusion for Retirement Accounts] for an excellent discussion, with illustrative examples, of how RMDs can interact with Roth conversions, rollovers and direct trustee transfers.</ref>
If you have multiple IRAs, even if they are held at different custodians, the total aggregated required minimum distribution (RMD) for those IRAs must be withdrawn before any Roth IRA conversion (or 60-day rollover) can be completed. It is not necessary to complete workplace retirement RMDs prior to the Roth conversion.<ref>{{ cite web|url= https://irahelp.com/slottreport/new-rule-all-ira-rmds-must-be-satisfied-prior-to-doing-a-roth-conversion | title= New Rule: All IRA RMDs Must Be Satisfied Prior to Doing a Roth Conversion|publisher= Ed Slott and Company, LLC }} </ref>
===Qualified Charitable Distributions=== {{Main|Qualified charitable distributions}}
Qualified Charitable Distributions (QCDs) allow IRA owners and beneficiaries to satisfy part or all of their RMD by giving money directly to a qualifying non-profit organization. QCDs are limited to $105,000 in 2024 and $108,000 in 2025. For married joint filers, this limit applies separately to each spouse.
===Penalties===
The penalties for failing to take a RMD are large: 25% of the balance that should have been distributed. For this reason, correctly calculating and taking RMDs should be a top financial priority for those affected. Penalties for insufficient or late RMDs are assessed using [https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/f5329.pdf IRS Form 5329]. The IRS does sometimes waive such penalties.<ref name="IRS signals">{{cite web| url=https://irahelp.com/irs-signals-it-will-still-waive-missed-rmd-penalties/| title=IRS Signals That It Will Still Waive Missed RMD Penalties| publisher=Ed Slott and Company, LLC| date=April 10, 2023| accessdate=October 19, 2025}}</ref>
===Disabled or chronically ill beneficiaries===
To be considered disabled or chronically ill, beneficiaries must prove they are disabled or chronically ill at the time the account owner died. Evidence must be submitted by October 31 of the year following the owner's death.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://retirementlc.com/resources/disabled-and-chronically-ill-eligible-designated-beneficiaries/ | title=Disabled and Chronically Ill Eligible Designated Beneficiaries |publisher=Retirement Learning Center | date=November 25, 2024}}</ref>
==Examples==
===Example 1===
Alice is Bob's daughter. In 2022, Alice turned 35 and Bob turned 65, but he died before the end of the year. Alice was the sole beneficiary of Bob's [[traditional IRA]]. The IRA had a balance of $805,904 on December 31, 2021. Bob withdrew $25,000 in 2022 before he died, but this did not matter for RMD purposes because no RMD is required for 2022, whether or not Bob died. Alice is a non-designated beneficiary, and because Bob died before reaching his required beginning date, Alice has no RMD requirements. However, she is subject to the 10-year rule and must completely empty the IRA by Dec 31, 20'''32'''.
=== Example 2===
Angie is Barry's daughter, and Barry is unmarried. In 2025, Angie turned 45 and Barry turned 80, but he died before the end of the year. Angie was the sole beneficiary of Barry's traditional IRA. The IRA had a balance of $1,221,867 on December 31, 2024. Barry withdrew $45,000 in 2025 before he died. Barry's RMD is calculated for 2025 based on his age on his birthday in 2025 (80) and [https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b#en_US_2024_publink100090310 Table III (Uniform Lifetime)], and is '''$60,488''' (= $1,221,867 / 20.2). Because Barry did not withdraw the full RMD before he died, Angie must withdraw the remainder of '''$15,488''' (= $60,488 - $45,000) before Dec 31, 202'''6''' (the end of the year after his death) to avoid penalties. Because Angie is not an eligible designated beneficiary, the ten-year rule applies. And, because Barry died after reaching his required beginning date, Angie must also take annual RMDs per the IRS guidance released in 2024. Her RMD in 2026 is calculated by the ''longer'' life expectancy from her age on her birthday in 2026 (46) and [https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b#en_US_2024_publink100089977 Table I (Single Life Expectancy)], or Barry's age in the year he died (80) and [https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b#en_US_2024_publink100089977 Table I (Single Life Expectancy)], minus one year. These two values are 40.0 and 10.2 (= 11.2 - 1) respectively. The account balance on Dec 31, 2025 is $1,338,942, so Angie's RMD in 2026 is '''$33,474''' (= $1,338,942 / 40.0), which must be taken out by Dec 31, 2026 in addition to the $15,488 remainder of Barry's 2025 RMD calculated above. The account balance on Dec 31, 2026 is $1,229,384, so Angie's RMD for 2027 is '''$31,523''' (= $1,229,384 / [40.0 - 1]). And, Angie must completely empty the IRA by Dec 31, 20'''35'''.
===Example 3=== Ann is Brian's sister, and Brian is unmarried. In 2025, Ann turned 80 and Brian turned 75, but he died before the end of the year. Ann was the sole beneficiary of Brian's traditional IRA, which had a balance of $482,989 on December 31, 2024. The RMD for the IRA in 2025 is calculated as though Brian were alive the entire year, and is '''$19,634''' (= $482,989 / 24.6). Brian did not take any distributions before he died, so Ann is responsible for withdrawing at least this amount before Dec 31, 2026 (per IRS guidance from 2024) to avoid penalties. The balance on Dec 31, 2025 is $501,159. Ann qualifies as an eligible designated beneficiary because she is not more than 10 years younger than Brian. Ann's RMD for 2026 is calculated based on the ''longer'' life expectancy from her age on her birthday in 2026 (81) and [https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b#en_US_2024_publink100089977 Table I (Single Life Expectancy)], or from Brian's age on the year of his death (75) and [https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b#en_US_2024_publink100089977 Table I (Single Life Expectancy)], minus one year. These two values are 10.5 and 13.8 (= 14.8 - 1) respectively, so the RMD is '''$36,316''' (= $501,159 / 13.8). Ann must distribute a total of $55,950 (Brian's remaining RMD from 2025 and Ann's RMD from 2026) by Dec 31, 2026 to avoid penalties. The balance on Dec 31, 2026 is $472,262. For 2027, Ann's RMD is calculated based on the ''longer'' life expectancy from her age on her birthday in 2026 (81) and [https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b#en_US_2024_publink100089977 Table I (Single Life Expectancy)], minus one year, or from Brian's age on the year of his death (75) and [https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b#en_US_2024_publink100089977 Table I (Single Life Expectancy)], minus two years. These two values are 9.5 (= 10.5 - 1) and 12.8 (= 14.8 - 2) respectively, so the RMD is '''$36,895''' (= $472,262 / 12.8).
===Example 4=== Allison and Bill are married. In 2025, Allison turned 55 and Bill would have turned 75, but he died in 2025 before his birthday. Allison was the sole beneficiary of Bill's traditional IRA, and she elected to treat it as an Inherited IRA rather than her own, so she can take penalty-free withdrawals before age 59½. Even though she inherited the IRA after January 1, 2020, the SECURE Act provides an exception to the ten-year rule for surviving spouses electing to treat the IRA as their own (thus Allison is an eligible designated beneficiary), so the pre-SECURE Act Stretch IRA rules apply. The IRA had a balance of $1,221,867 on December 31, 2024. Bill's RMD for 2025 is as though he were alive for the entire year, and is calculated based on [https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b#en_US_2024_publink100090290 Table II (Joint and Last Survivor Life Expectancy)] (ages 55 and 75) because his spouse is the sole beneficiary and more than 10 years younger. The RMD for 2025 is '''$37,712''' (= $1,221,867 / 32.4), and because Bill did not make any withdrawals in 2025 before his death, Allison is responsible for taking this entire withdrawal before Dec 31, 2026 (per IRS guidance from 2024) to avoid penalties. The balance on Dec 31, 2025 is $1,252,574. For 2026, Alice's RMD is based on the longer life expectancy of herself in 2026 (age 56) per [https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b#en_US_2024_publink100089977 Table I (Single Life Expectancy)], or Bill's age on his birthday the year he died (75) per [https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b#en_US_2024_publink100089977 Table I (Single Life Expectancy)], with one year subtracted. These two values are 30.6 and 13.8 (= 14.8 - 1). So, her RMD in 2026 is '''$40,934''' (= $1,252,574 / 30.6). The total amount Allison must withdraw by Dec 31, 2026, including Bill's 2025 RMD, is $78,646 (= $37,712 + 40,934). The balance on Dec 31, 2026 is $1,402,359. For 2027, Alice's RMD is based on the longer life expectancy of herself in 2027 (age 57) per [https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b#en_US_2024_publink100089977 Table I (Single Life Expectancy)], or Bill's age the year he died (75) per [https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b#en_US_2024_publink100089977 Table I (Single Life Expectancy)], minus two years. These values are 29.8 and 12.8 (= 14.8 - 2) respectively. So, her RMD in 2027 is '''$47,059''' (= $1,402,359 / 29.8).
==Managing RMDs==
For most retirees — especially in the early years — RMDs generally align with [[safe withdrawal rates]] and can serve as a practical source of income. There is usually no need to avoid RMDs unless your retirement accounts are significantly larger than your expected spending. Unwanted RMDs can often be mitigated via Roth [[Traditional versus Roth|contributions]]/[[Roth conversion|conversions]] and [[Qualified charitable distributions|Qualified Charitable Distributions (QCDs)]].
===RMDs throughout retirement===
The RMD amount varies each year based on investment performance. This table shows the expected size of RMDs throughout retirement, adjusted for inflation, as a function of the overall account real rate of return, expressed as a percentage of the first-year RMD for an investor with an RMD age of 73.

For a reasonable rate of rate of return (up to ~5% real) and average life expectancy (for someone who has reached age 73, approximately 85 for a male and 87 for a female), RMDs should stay below about 200% of the first-year RMD. Many investors will have a high percentage of lower-risk lower-return investments like [[Bond basics|bonds]] and have RMDs stay even flatter. However, the combination of high returns and long life can produce some large RMDs. If this possibility is one you want to avoid, Roth conversions both before and during retirement will lower RMDs.
===RMDs versus annuitization===
The distribution rules were made more generous in recent years and appear to work better than many annuities. If only the RMD percentage is taken in bull or bear market years, the amount of money withdrawn will be increased some years and reduced some years but will theoretically never run out. Of course, a severe long term decline like the Japanese scenario might make the amount of money insufficient to support required retirement expenses. Portfolio allocations for retirees dependent upon investments for a significant portion of their living expenses should be conservative anyway (higher percentage of fixed income reducing the equity risk). Keeping investments in an IRA also lets you retain more flexibility than annuitization, for example by allowing adjustment of [[asset allocation]], reinvestment of unspent RMDs in a taxable account, leaving an IRA to a spouse who can treat it as their own, and leaving to non-spouse heirs with a 10-year stretch.
The consensus opinion is that annuitization should only be considered when you have just about enough savings to provide for your desired retirement income, and want to purchase longevity insurance at the expense of leaving less money to heirs. See: [[Immediate fixed annuity]] for details on the trade-offs for annuitization.
===Disclaiming all or part of an inherited account===
Beneficiaries can manage RMDs by disclaiming all or part of their account. The account then passes to the next eligible beneficiary on the account, and the new beneficiary becomes responsible for RMDs. This can be particularly powerful if the new beneficiary is disabled or chronically ill, as the beneficiary in that situation can take RMDs over their single life expectancy.
===Tax management=== If your objective is minimizing taxes on RMDs, taking more than the RMD can make sense in some scenarios.
One example is the 10-year rule. If the balance of the account is large enough to push you into a higher tax bracket in year 10, it's rarely the right decision to wait until year 10 to take distributions. Instead, take the distributions over multiple years to minimize the tax impact.
[[Stretch IRA]] has an extensive discussion of tax management strategies.
=== Prefer in-kind distributions when possible ===
Consider this scenario:
:Sally is 75 years old and owns a traditional IRA and a brokerage account. She holds VTI in the traditional IRA, has no need for additional cash, and would like to invest her RMD in VTI in her brokerage account.
In this scenario, Sally should transfer shares in-kind from her IRA, rather than selling VTI in the IRA, transferring cash, and buying VTI in her brokerage account. Benefits of this approach include:
* Cleaner tax reporting * Shares retain their original purchase date, for wash sale calculation purposes * Money stays in market during RMD process
In-kind distributions and cash distributions are both taxed as ordinary income. Shares distributed in-kind get a new cost basis equal to their fair market value when distributed.
==Individual Retirement Annuity==
Individual Retirement Annuity<ref>{{cite web|title=Individual Retirement Annuity: What It Is and It Works| author=Julia Kagan| publisher=Investopedia | url=https://www.investopedia.com/terms/i/individual_retirement_annuity.asp|access-date=October 12, 2025}}</ref> is a type of IRA where the retirement account is funded through an annuity contract issued by an insurance company. When calculating RMDs, the ''entire interest'' includes the value of any riders that provide additional benefits. Your insurance company will provide you with your ''entire interest'' if it is more than the ''account balance''.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title=Qualified pension, profit-sharing, and stock bonus plans|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/26/401|access-date=September 10, 2025|series=26 USC §401(a)(9)(A)|publisher=Office of the Law Revision Counsel of the US House of Representatives}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Required minimum distributions from defined contribution plans|url=https://www.ecfr.gov/current/title-26/chapter-I/subchapter-A/part-1/subject-group-ECFR6f8c3724b50e44d/section-1.401(a)(9)-5|access-date=January 8, 2022|series=26 CFR §1.401(a)(9)-5(A-1)(a)|publisher=Code of Federal Regulations}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|title=Required minimum distributions from defined contribution plans|url=https://www.ecfr.gov/current/title-26/chapter-I/subchapter-A/part-1/subject-group-ECFR6f8c3724b50e44d/section-1.401(a)(9)-5|access-date=January 8, 2022|series=26 CFR §1.401(a)(9)-5(A-1)(e)|publisher=Code of Federal Regulations}}</ref>
Individual Retirement Annuity contracts do not use the RMD tables once you have purchased a lifetime annuity with regular payments, but do use the RMD tables based on the entire interest otherwise.<ref group="note">Details are in the Code of Federal Regulations, 26 CFR §1.401(a)(9)-5, [https://www.ecfr.gov/current/title-26/chapter-I/subchapter-A/part-1/subject-group-ECFR6f8c3724b50e44d/section-1.401(a)(9)-5 Required minimum distributions from defined contribution plans.], A-1. (a) ''General rule.'' - Uses the RMD tables., A-1. (e) ''Annuity contracts.'' - Applies for annuities.<br> An annuity can be a container for investments. It can also be a stream of payments. An annuity before you annuitize it is a container for investments. It becomes a stream of payments after it is annuitized.</ref>
You have the option of emptying your account so you will have no further RMDs. For an Individual Retirement Account, you can withdraw all your money; for an Individual Retirement Annuity, you can purchase a life annuity with regular payments.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />

A '''variable annuity''' is an insurance contract that delays payments of income (periodic or systematic withdrawals, or annuitized payouts) until the investor elects to receive them. This type of annuity has two main phases, the savings phase in which you invest money into the account, and the income phase in which the plan is converted into income and payments are received. Earnings within the contract are tax deferred, and are taxed upon withdrawal at income tax rates (similar to qualified retirement plans) and share with these plans the 10% early penalty tax for withdrawals made prior to age 59 and 1/2. If the annuity is held within a retirement plan it is known as a "qualified" annuity and distributions are totally taxable. If the annuity is purchased in the taxable account it is known as a "non-qualified" variable annuity and only the earnings are subject to tax. Variable annuity withdrawals are made on an earnings first, basis last principle. Variable annuities come with an array of insurance options, all of which add to the cost of investment in the contract. These guarantees are subject to the continuing claims paying solvency of the insurer.<ref>[http://www.sec.gov/investor/pubs/varannty.htm SEC:Variable Annuities:What You Should Know] Vanguard Variable Annuity Prospectus, 2008.</ref>
==Variable annuity components== ===The variable account=== Investments in a variable annuity are placed in what is termed a Separate Account, which is an account segregated from an insurer's general account and is exempt from the insurer's creditors. The assets in the account are thus safe from an insurer's default. Investors are provided with a menu of subaccounts, pooled investment vehicles analogous to mutual funds, offering access to stocks, bonds, and money market instruments. The annuity investor's capital will fluctuate with the returns of the underlying subaccount investments. The terminology used in connection with a subaccount, along with the analogous mutual fund terminology is provided in the following table:<ref name="vanguard">Vanguard Variable Annuity Prospectus, 2008.</ref>
<center> {| class=wikitable style="text-align:left" width=400px |+ '''Variable Annuity Terminology''' ! style="background:#f0f0f0;"|'''Variable Annuity''' ! style="background:#f0f0f0;"|'''Mutual Fund''' |- | Subaccount||Mutual Fund |- | Accumulation Unit ||Mutual Fund Share |- | Accumulation Unit Value||Net Asset Value |- | Accumulation Value||Account Value |- |} </center>
Dividends and capital gains distributions do not add accumulation units to your subaccount; they are added into the accumulation unit value.
===The death benefit=== The basic insurance benefit associated with a variable annuity is the death benefit. The benefit assures the beneficiaries of the annuity a guaranteed payment if the contract owner dies prior to annuitizing the contract. The benefit is usually offered with variations. Fees for these benefits will be discussed later. :*'''Return of premium''':The return of premium death benefit guarantees that the beneficiary will receive either the current market value of the contract or the premiums (net of any withdrawals) paid into the contract. :*'''Stepped-up death benefit''': This death benefit guarantees the beneficiary will receive either the full account value at the time of death or the highest account value on any contract anniversary prior to death, whichever is greater. :*'''Stepped-up benefit with accumulation''': This option guarantees the beneficiary will receive either the greater of the stepped up death benefit or the total contributions accumulated at a certain annual percentage rate, less any withdrawals.<ref name="vanguard" />
===Living benefits=== Many variable annuities offer guarantee options to insure a given level of retirement income, or accumulation value. These guarantees come at an added cost. The main Living Benefit options include: :*'''Guaranteed Minimum Income Benefit''': This option ensures that if you purchase a variable annuity during one of the financial market peaks and end up requiring retirement payments during one of the market’s troughs, you will still receive a predictable minimum level of retirement payments after a certain agreed-upon date. Should the underlying investments perform well, then your payments may be higher than this guaranteed amount. To initiate the guaranteed minimum income benefit, you must annuitize the contract. :*'''Guaranteed Minimum Accumulation Benefit''': This optional feature protects your contribution against market volatility. Typically, a portion of your original contribution is invested in a fixed interest account that is guaranteed to grow to the size of your principal after a specified period of time, while the remainder is invested in variable investment portfolios. Some versions of this benefit, in addition to guaranteeing your principal or original contribution, also guarantee a certain minimum level of accumulation. :*'''Guaranteed Minimum Withdrawal Benefit''': This optional benefit guarantees that regardless of market performance, you will be able to receive at least the entire amount of your total principal investment through a series of annual withdrawals – provided that you do not withdraw more than a specified percentage of your total investment in any given year. Some variable annuities are now offering this benefit with the guarantee that you can make withdrawals for as long as you live.<ref name="lambert">Georgg D.Lambert. [http://www.investopedia.com/articles/pf/06/variableannuity.asp?viewed=1 The Cost Of Variable Annuity Guarantees]</ref> :*'''Guaranteed Lifetime Withdrawal Benefit (GLWB)''':The GLWB guarantees that you can withdraw a minimum amount throughout your lifetime - regardless of the subaccounts' performance - and you don't have to annuitize your contract. The guarantee is a set percentage of your investment, which increases the longer you delay taking payments. For example, the company might agree to pay you 5% at age 55. But if you wait until you are 70 to begin taking income, the company might increase that to 5.5%. At age 80, it could be 6%.<ref name="lambert" />
==Variable annuity expenses== {{Notice|Each of the above features and options are available for a fee. In 2011, Morningstar reports the average cost of a variable annuity as 2.49%. The accumulation of fees and surrender charges can make the average VA a prohibitively expensive investment vehicle. Investors can reduce the costs associated with a VA by directly investing in a no-load, no surrender fee VA with low insurance and subaccount cost loadings.}}
The fees associated with a variable annuity include the following charges. :*'''Mortality and expense risk charge''': This charge covers the insurer's costs for guaranteeing an annuity payout rate, as well as other insurance and administrative charges. This charge often contains the cost for providing a basic death benefit.The average basic death benefit costs between 0.15% and 0.35%<ref name="lambert" /> :*'''Account maintenance fee''' This is usually a flat fee ($25-$35) assessed annually to the contract to cover the costs maintaining the account. The fee usually is waived at a certain account size level. The average VA asset based administrative and recordkeeping fee for 2008 was 0.25%. :*'''Underlying subaccount fees''': Subaccounts have expense ratios just as do mutual funds. Average variable annuity subaccount [[Expense ratios | expense ratios]] are lower than average mutual fund expense ratios. Morningstar reports the 2011 average VA subaccount ER as 0.96%. :*'''Death benefit fees''':The cost for enhanced death benefits ranges from .010% to 0.40%.<ref name="lambert" /> :*'''Living benefit fees''': :** Guaranteed Minimum Income Benefit, average fee, 0.781%. :** Guaranteed Minimum Accumulation Benefit, average fee, 0.76%. :** Guaranteed Minimum Withdrawal, average fee, 0.836%. :** Guaranteed Lifetime Withdrawal, average fee, 1.121%.<ref> Kevin Loffredi, [https://www.myirionline.org/eweb/uploads/Q3%202011%20Product%20Update%20Report.pdf Carriers Settle In: Variable Annuity Product Development Slows in Third Quarter], Morningstar </ref> :*'''Surrender charges''': Most variable annuities impose a surrender charge for withdrawals from or exchanges out of the contract. The percentage charge usually declines over time (usually 7 or 8 years) until it disappears. Some VAs impose a surrender charge on each investment you make in the contract. Many contracts allow you to withdraw a certain percentage of the account value (often 10%-15%) per year without incurring the surrender charge. . :*'''Premium taxes''': Some states assess a regulatory tax on each variable annuity investment payment; other states assess a tax on accumulated annuity values which are annuitized and not taken as a lump sum.<ref name="vanguard" />
<center> {| class=wikitable style="text-align:center" width=450px |+'''States With A Premium Tax on VA Investment''' ! style="background:#f0f0f0;"|'''State''' ! style="background:#f0f0f0;"|'''Qualifying''' ! style="background:#f0f0f0;"|'''Non-Qualifying''' |- |align="left"| Maine|| 0.00%|| 2.00% |- |align="left"| South Dakota|| 0.00%|| 1.25% |- | align="left"| Wyoming|| 0.00%||1.00% |- |} </center>
<center> {| class=wikitable style="text-align:center" width=450px |+ '''States With A Premium Tax on Annuitized Contracts''' ! style="background:#f0f0f0;"|'''State''' ! style="background:#f0f0f0;"|'''Qualifying''' ! style="background:#f0f0f0;"|'''Non-Qualifying''' |- | align="left"| California|| 0.50%|| 2.35% |- | align="left"|Nevada|| 0.00%|| 3.50% |- | align="left"|West Virginia||1.00%|| 1.00% |- |} </center>
==The income phase== When it comes time to take income from a variable annuity you have three options: :# You can make aperiodic withdrawals from the VA. With aperiodic withdrawals you retain control of the annuity's capital. :# You can make [[Systematic withdrawal | systematic withdrawal]]s from the VA. A systematic withdrawal can be either a fixed percentage of the account balance, or a fixed regular withdrawal of a set dollar amount. With systematic withdrawals you retain control of the annuity's capital. :# You can annuitize the VA. The decision to annuitize is irrevocable. With this option, you usually surrender control over the VA capital in return for an income stream. An annuitization can be either a [[Immediate fixed annuity |fixed immediate annuity]], or a [[Immediate variable annuity |variable immediate annuity]], or a combination of the two.
==Variable annuity taxation== If a variable annuity is held within a qualified plan, the annuity is taxed according to the tax rules governing the qualified plan. Non-qualified variable annuities are subject to the following tax rules. All income is taxed at an individual's marginal income tax rate.
:*The VA, similar to other retirement vehicles, is subject to a 10% early withdrawal penalty for withdrawals made prior to age 59 and 1/2. Exceptions to the penalty include: :** The owner is over age 59½; :** The owner is disabled after contract purchase; :** The owner, not the non-owner annuitant, dies; :** Pre-TEFRA (prior to 8/14/82 contributions) nonqualified money; :** Immediate nonqualified annuity (Note: An exchange from a deferred to an immediate annuity does not qualify as an immediate annuity for the purposes of avoiding tax penalty); :** [[SEPP:Substantially Equal Periodic Payments|Substantially Equal Periodic Payments]].<ref name="non-qualified">[http://www.immediateannuities.com/library_articles/taxation_of_nonqual_annuities.htm Non-Qualified Annuity Tax Rules]</ref>
:* Non-qualified VAs are not subject to the required minimum distribution rules. This allows you to potentially continue to defer taxes past the 70 and 1/2 age required distribution date that applies to [[Traditional IRA|traditional IRAs]] and qualified plans (if you are not still working). Most VAs do have a point (frequently age 85) where you are required to annuitize the contract.
:* VA withdrawals are made on an earnings first, basis last principle. An exception applies to pre-TEFRA contributions to an annuity made prior to 8/14/82. Withdrawals from these contracts are on a basis first, earnings last principle.
:* VA ownership transfers such as: :** Addition/deletion of joint owner; :** Transfer to another individual or entity; :** Assignment; :* Can have the following tax consequences: :** Earnings are subject to income tax at time of transfer; :** 10% penalty may apply; :** Gift taxes may apply; :* Exceptions to tax: :** Transfers between spouses; :** Transfers incident to divorce; :** Transfers between an individual and their grantor trust;<ref name="non-qualified" />
:* Upon annuitization each VA income payment represents a return of non-taxable investment in the contract with the balance of each payment considered taxable income. The taxable and non-taxable portions of the payments are determined by an exclusion ratio, determined for a variable annuity by dividing the investment in the contract by the total number of expected payments. Once the total amount of the investment in the contract is recovered, the annuity payments are fully taxable. If the owner dies before the total investment in the contract is recovered, and annuity payments cease as a result of his death, the un-recovered amount is allowed as a deduction to the owner on the final tax return.<ref name="non-qualified" />
:*For variable annuity contracts issued on or after 10/29/79 there is no "step-up" in basis for income tax purposes and the beneficiary pays income tax on the earnings. If the annuity is subject to estate tax, the beneficiary is entitled to deduct a portion of estate tax paid on the annuity for income tax purposes. For variable annuity contracts issued prior to 10/21/79, there is a "step-up" in basis for income tax purposes and no income tax is payable on the earnings.<ref name="non-qualified" />
==Distributions upon the death of the variable annuity owner== A surviving non-spouse joint owner or beneficiary of a non-qualified VA must select one of the following distribution options for a VA inherited during the accumulation phase of the contract: :* immediate lump sum; :* according to the five-year rule with complete withdrawal(s) within 5 years of the contract owner's death; :* annuitization (over the life of the new owner) to start within one year of the contract owner's death.
A spousal co-owner or beneficiary has the option of assuming the variable annuity as their own.<ref name="non-qualified" />
The income over basis in a variable annuity is considered [[Income in respect of a decedent | income in respect of a decedent]]. This means that the increase in value inside a deferred variable annuity does not receive stepped up valuation upon the death of the contract owner. The beneficiary assumes both the decedent's basis in the annuity, as well as the same tax character of the income. Should a decedent's estate pay estate tax the portion of the tax attributable to the estate's IRD is deductible as a miscellaneous itemized deduction (not subject to the 2% AGI exclusion) to the beneficiary receiving the IRD. The deduction is figured by computing the estate tax due on the entire estate and computing the estate tax due on the estate minus all IRD. The difference between the two provides the deductible amount. The deduction is realized on the IRD as the IRD is paid out to the beneficiary.<ref name="non-qualified" />
The beneficiary's right to income after the death of the annuitant during the annuitization phase of a variable annuity will depend on the annuitization option selected (single life, joint life, or the selection of a guaranteed period).<ref name="non-qualified" />
==The 1035 exchange== The IRS allows you to make tax free transfers of annuities through what is known as a 1035 exchange. Since variable annuities are typically burdened with high insurance costs and stiff back end surrender fees, a tax-free exchange of high cost contracts to no-load, no surrender fee, low cost annuities is clearly warranted for most non-qualifying annuities. Low cost VAs are offered by [http://personal.fidelity.com/products/annuities/?bar=c Fidelity] and [http://www.tiaa-cref.org/products/annuities/index.html TIAA-CREF]. The [http://www.investopedia.com/terms/s/sec1035ex.asp 1035 transfer] decision can be quantified using a spreadsheet template similar to the one offered by Dr. Moshe Milevsky as an adjunct to his paper [http://www.ifid.ca/pdf_workingpapers/WP2003DEC19.pdf Exchanging Variable Annuities: An Optional Test for Suitability]. The annuity option variables to include in a calculation are (quoting Milevsky):
# '''Lapse value'''. This captures the cash-flow that comes from liquidating or surrendering the policy – possibly after paying a contingent deferred surrender charge (CDSC) – and is tied to the evolution of the market value of the sub-accounts. Most investors purchase VAs exclusively for their lapse value since they view the instrument as a (tax-preferred) savings vehicle. Therefore, when contemplating an exchange, the policy holder should be aware of the discounted lapse value (DLV) of the new policy. All else being equal, the greater the contingent deferred surrender charges (CDSC) on the new policy and/or the greater the Mortality and Expense Risk Fees (from here, abbreviated M&E Fee) relative to the old policy, the lower the discounted lapse value, and the less likely it is that an exchange will add economic value to the investor. # '''Death value'''. Most VA policies contain some form of guaranteed minimum death benefit. This guarantee comes in various shapes and flavors, but usually consists of a return-of-premium guarantee together with a minimally guaranteed interest rate and/or anniversary step-up feature, which periodically raises the minimum guarantee to market value. And, while these guaranteed minimum death benefits (GMDB)5 (as they are collectively known) have become a recent nuisance to the risk management and treasury departments within the insurance companies issuing these policies, the fact is that most consumers are more likely to lapse their VA than die and cash-in on the GMDB. Nevertheless, this embedded option must be priced in any transaction and we use the term discounted mortality value (DMV) to denote the current value of this guarantee. # '''Guaranteed annuity rates'''. All variable annuity policies contain an option to annuitize – in the form of a guaranteed mortality table and interest rate -- which is poorly understood and usually ignored. Many older VAs contain annuity rate guarantees that are linked to outdated mortality tables and are thus more valuable, relative to updated mortality tables that assume a longer life expectancy. More recent VA policies offer optional guaranteed minimum income benefit (GMIB) riders which are a form of guaranteed annuity rate. In general, we use the term discounted annuity value (DAV) to denote the collection of options associated with the ability to annuitize the policy at a pre-specified mortality table and interest rate.
The spreadsheet program for quantifying the 1035 exchange can be downloaded [http://www.ifid.ca/annuities_exchanging.htm here]. [Please note that this spreadsheet is made available for educational purposes, not for commercial use.]
Inputs for the spreadsheet include:
* The client's age; * The capital value of the Annuity. This allows you to account for any conditional surrender fees assessed upon transfer; * The death benefit value. For a client's current contract, this value can be either "in the money" or "out of the money." An "in the money" death benefit would potentially apply to contract values after a bear market, where the insured death benefit could be greater than the current market value of the contract. A transfer would negate this insured value since the new contract would, assuming the election of a death benefit, insure only the current market value of the portfolio. In most cases, the death benefit will be "out of the money", meaning that, assuming the election of a death benefit, the new contract will provide for a higher insured value for the transferred portfolio. Vanguard offers their VA with a zero death benefit at reduced cost. The program does not allow a zero input, so you should either input a nominal value or an estimated maximum downside risk value for this zero death benefit input. * The expense ratios of the two contracts; * The assumed volatility of the two portfolios (standard deviation); * The risk-free rate of return.
The output will provide the economic value of the proposed transfer. Positive values indicate that a transfer is economically suitable. Negative values indicate that a transfer is economically unsuitable.

{{US|reason=irrelevant}}
An '''immediate variable annuity '''is a financial contract between you and an insurance company. You give the company money now and the company pays you an income at a later time.
Income annuities can be [[Immediate fixed annuity | fixed]] or variable. The payments from variable income annuities discussed here fluctuate and are based on the performance of the investment options you choose. Although payments may go up or down, [[Variable Annuity|variable annuities]] are designed to provide income that can rise over time to help you keep pace with inflation. Immediate annuities are often designated as Single Premium Immediate Annuities (SPIA) to differentiate them from deferred annuities.
==Annuity units== Investments in an immediate variable annuity are placed in what is termed a Separate Account, which is an account segregated from an insurer's general account and is exempt from the insurer's creditors. Investors are provided with a menu of subaccounts, pooled investment vehicles analogous to mutual funds, offering access to stocks, bonds, and money market instruments. The annuity investor's capital will fluctuate with the returns of the underlying subaccount investments. The terminology used in connection with a subaccount, along with the analogous mutual fund terminology is provided in the following table:<ref>Vanguard Variable Annuity Prospectus, 2008.</ref>
<center> {| class=wikitable style="text-align:left" width=400px |+ '''Variable Annuity Terminology''' ! style="background:#f0f0f0;"|'''Variable Annuity''' ! style="background:#f0f0f0;"|'''Mutual Fund''' |- | Subaccount||Mutual Fund |- | Accumulation Unit ||Mutual Fund Share |- | Accumulation Unit Value||Net Asset Value |- | Accumulation Value||Account Value |- |} </center>
The basic construct of an immediate variable annuity (SPIA) is the annuity unit. The unit is computed according to three factors applied to the specific chosen distribution option and life expectancy of the investor:
:# The monthly payment per $1,000 invested. Using an assumed interest rate (AIR) and mortality assumptions, an actuary can price the initial annuity payment. :#The amount invested. :#The accumulated unit value (AUV) of the underlying subaccount portfolio.
As a simplfied example, assume that the actuary provides a $6.00 monthly payment per $1000 invested; an investor invests $50,000 in a balanced subaccount fund; and the AUV of the subaccount fund is $10.00. The following computation yields the number of annuity units.
(50 x 6.00)/10.00 = 30.00 annuity units. The initial monthly income from this subaaccount fund would, in this instance, equal 30.00 x 10.00= $300.00.<ref>Daily, Glenn, S. “The attractions and pitfalls of variable immediate annuities,” AAII Journal, (February 1994)</ref>
This is the key to the insurer's lifetime income guarantee. With a life annuity, the annuitant will be paid 30.00 annuity units for life. Gross fund performance minus fund and insurance expenses, and the AIR will determine the ensuing payments.
==Assumed interest rate (AIR)== The AIR assumes two pivotal valuation functions for a variable SPIA. It determines the initial annuity income payment as well as the variable adjustments to income. The AIR usually ranges from 3% to 7%. Vanguard<ref>[http://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/866252/000119312509022610/d485apos.htm Vanguard VA Prospectus] p.10.</ref> and TIAA-CREF<ref>[http://connect.rightprospectus.com/TIAA/TADF/194408803/P?site=VA CREF Annuities prospectus] p.101.</ref> use a 4% AIR in their existing VA contracts.
The higher the initial AIR, the higher the initial payment. Later income appreciation will be slower with a high AIR, and income losses likelier. A lower AIR results in a smaller initial income, but produces faster income appreciation, thus providing better hedging against inflation risk, as well as smaller income losses during down markets.<ref>[http://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/820627/000119312508096683/d485bpos.txt Vanguard Lifetime Income prospectus] p.32.</ref> It is important to note, however, that all AIR income streams are actuarially equivalent. In addition, because the AIR discount rate is applied to the more reliable expected mortality experience of a pooled cohort of annuitants, the initial income payout for an annuitization of a lump sum (for retirement age annuitants) is frequently higher than the income from an equal systematic withdrawal rate applied to the same lump sum. Below are the monthly income implications for both a 3.5% AIR and a 7% AIR, assuming 10% and -10 % returns:
::<u>3.5% AIR</u> *10 percent gain: (1.10/1.035-1)= 6.28% *10 percent loss: (0.90/1.035-1)= -13.04%
::<u>7.0% AIR</u> *10 percent gain:(1.10/1.070-1)= 2.80% *10 percent loss:(0.90/1.070-1)= -15.89%
==The exclusion ratio== Variable immediate annuities receive a degree of tax relief (for non-qualified dollars) due to the income exclusion rules. The IRS allows the investment in the contract to be recovered over the annuitant's life expectancy. In our previous example of a $50,000 initial investment and a 20-year life expectancy, approximately $2500 of the annual income stream would be a tax-free return of principal for 20 years. After year 20, the full income payment will be taxed. If the owner dies before the total investment in the contract is recovered, and annuity payments cease as a result of his death, the un-recovered amount is allowed as a deduction to the owner on the final tax return.<ref>Babbel, David F., and Reddy, Ravi, [http://fic.wharton.upenn.edu/fic/Policy%20page/AnnuityTaxation1.pdf "Measuring the Tax Benefit of a Tax-Deferred Annuity"], Wharton Financial Institutions Center Policy Brief: Personal Finance, (October 4, 2008} </ref>
==Fundamental common benefits== Almost all variable SPIAs allow the investor to choose an initial asset allocation for the portfolio. After annuitization, the investor loses control of the invested capital, but can still maintain control of the asset allocations of the underlying portfolio. This allows the investor to maintain control of the expected returns and risk parameters of the portfolio income stream. Many immediate variable SPIAs also allow the investor to reallocate annuity units into the insurer's general account and the [[Immediate fixed annuity | fixed immediate annuity]] payout option.
Usually the investor is given flexibility in timing the investment stream (monthly, quarterly, annually) as well as the periodicity of the variable income adjustments (monthly vs. annually).
==Income options== Common income options for immediate variable annuities include the following four optiions.
*'''Single life annuity''': As the annuitant, you receive regular income payments for your lifetime, ending at your death. (Payments are largest with this option.) *'''Joint and survivor annuity''':Payments are made as long as you (the annuitant) or another person (the joint annuitant), such as your spouse, are living. Many annuities allow you to select a percentage (50%, 66.67%, 75% or 100%) of the amount that was payable while the annuitant was alive to go to the joint surviving annuitant. *'''Single life with a guarantee''':As the annuitant, you receive payments as long as you live, but not less than a guaranteed period. If you die before the period ends, your beneficiaries receive the remaining payments. The guaranteed period may cover 5 to 50 years for nonqualified (after-tax) assets and up to your life expectancy for qualified (pre-tax) assets. *'''Joint and survivor with a guarantee''':Payments are made as long as you (the annuitant) or another person (the joint annuitant) are living, but not less than a guaranteed period. If both you and the joint annuitant die before the period ends, your beneficiaries receive the remaining payments. The guaranteed period may cover 5 to 50 years for nonqualified (after-tax) assets and up to your life expectancy for qualified (pre-tax) assets.<ref>Merkel, Stephen,[http://www.investopedia.com/articles/retirement/05/071105.asp Selecting The Payout On Your Annuity] Investopedia</ref>
The addition of a guarantee option will reduce the income payment from the annuity.
==Commutation and withdrawals of principal== Many immediate variable annuities grant an annuitant who has selected a life annuity with a guarantee period the right to commute the annuity stream into a lump sum payment. Reflecting the reduced capital providing for the income stream, a commutation results in both a lower ensuing income and a shorter guarantee period.<ref>[http://www.standard.com/annuities/eforms/13020.pdf Commutation on Life Income Payments] policy illustration</ref>
If the variable SPIA offers a Guaranteed Minimum Withdrawal Benefit (at a higher cost) this optional benefit guarantees, regardless of market performance, that you will be able to receive at least the entire amount of your total principal investment through a series of annual withdrawals – provided that you do not withdraw more than a specified percentage of your total investment in any given year. Some variable annuities are now offering this benefit with the guarantee that you can make withdrawals for as long as you live.<ref>Devine, Colin, Hunt, Heather L. and Walsh, Keith, [http://www.peterkatt.com/newsletters/SmithBarney.pdf "The New Variable Annuity"] Smith Barney (September 14, 2004). p.21.</ref>
