{{US|reason=irrelevant}} Certain types of tax-advantaged accounts have '''early withdrawal''' penalties if you withdraw money from the account before reaching a certain age and an exception doesn't apply. Most retirement accounts ([[401(k)|401(k)s]], [[403(b)|403(b)s]], [[IRA|IRAs]], and others) have a 10% penalty for withdrawals before age 59½, but there are many exceptions. Many types of annuities have this early withdrawal penalty as well. [[Health savings account|Health Savings Accounts (HSAs)]] have a 20% penalty for non-qualified withdrawals (that is, not for qualified medical expenses) before age 65. This page provides the details of these penalties, and the exceptions to them. Just because you can take penalty-free withdrawals doesn't necessarily mean you ''should''. Withdrawing early from a retirement account foregoes future tax-deferred or tax-free growth, and will prolong the time it takes to become financially independent. Make sure any withdrawals fit within your overall financial plan. [[Taxable account|Taxable accounts]] have no early withdrawal penalties. ==Retirement accounts== Retirement accounts generally have a '''10%''' early withdrawal penalty if you withdraw money before age 59½.Age 59½ is defined as 6 months after your 59th birthday. For example, if you turn 59 on March 15th, then you turn 59½ on September 15th. Penalties are determined using the actual day of the withdrawal - that is, if you withdraw on September 14th, you will owe the penalty. However, there are many exceptions that can allow you to access money in retirement accounts before you turn 59½ without penalty: *Contributions to a [[Roth IRA]] can always be withdrawn tax- and penalty-free. This also applies to [[401(k)#Roth_401(k)|Roth 401(k)]] contributions that are later rolled into a Roth IRA. Early withdrawals directly from a Roth 401(k) are more complicated and often incur tax on earnings; see [[#Roth_accounts|below]]. *The [[Rule of 55]] allows you to withdraw penalty-free from a 401(k) or 403(b) plan if you separate from that employer in or after the year you turn 55. The rule applies even if you separate early in the year and turn 55 much later the same year. It does not apply to money in any former employer's plans, or in an [[IRA]]. *You can set up a [[Roth_conversion#Roth_conversion_ladder|Roth conversion ladder]]. Each conversion has a 5-year clock before the converted amount can be withdrawn penalty-free, so if using this method for an [[early retirement]], you will need an alternate source of funding for the first 4-5 years if you want to avoid early withdrawal penalties. *You can set up a [[Substantially equal periodic payments|Substantially Equal Periodic Payments (SEPP)]] plan (also known as a Section 72(t) plan) from a [[401(k)]], [[403(b)]], or IRA. This plan allows you to take similarly-sized withdrawals penalty-free for at least five years or until you turn 59½, whichever is longer. *Although not technically an early withdrawal, a [[401(k)#Early_withdrawals_and_loans|plan loan]] from a 401(k) or 403(b) is another way to access funds penalty-free from these plans. *[[457(b)]] plans have no early withdrawal penalties, except when non-457(b) money is rolled into a 457(b) and later withdrawn early. The following table summarizes exceptions to the early withdrawal penalty from retirement accounts:{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/retirement-plans/plan-participant-employee/retirement-topics-exceptions-to-tax-on-early-distributions| title=Retirement topics - Exceptions to tax on early distributions| publisher=IRS| accessdate=August 27, 2025}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |+ Table 1. Exceptions to the early withdrawal penalty from retirement accounts |- !Exception !Limit !Employer plan
(for example, 401(k)) !IRA |- | Birth or adoption expenses || Up to $5,000 || X || X |- | Total and permanent disability || - || X || X |- | Disaster recovery || Up to $22,000 || X || X |- | Domestic abuse || Up to lesser of 50% of the balance or $10,000 || X || X |- | Higher education expenses || - || || X |- | Emergency personal expense || Up to $1,000/year || X || X |- | Emergency savings account || - || X || |- | Substantially Equal Periodic Payments (SEPP) || - || X || X |- | First-time home purchase || Up to $10,000 || || X |- | Medical expenses || In excess of 7.5% AGI || X || X |- | Unemployed health insurance premiums || - || || X |- | Military reservist called to active duty || - || X || X |- | Separation from service ([[Rule of 55]]) || - || X || |- | Terminal illness || - || X || |} In addition, there are exceptions to the penalty for administrative actions, including permissive withdrawals from a plan with auto-enrollment, corrective distributions, a Qualified Domestic Relations Order (QDRO), dividend pass-through from an Employee Stock Options Plan (ESOP), IRS levy, returned IRA contributions, and rollovers. Death is always an exception to early withdrawal penalties for every account. But, note that the [[Required Minimum Distribution|Required Minimum Distribution (RMD)]] rules for inherited accounts can be complex, and the penalties for failing to take RMDs are large. In addition, you may be able to realize significant tax savings by tax-planning. Expert guidance is recommended when inheriting a retirement account. See also: [[Stretch IRA]]. Whether an employer plan allows distributions and whether early withdrawal penalties apply are two different things, the former being governed by the plan and the latter by IRS rules. Employer plans are only required to allow withdrawals when you separate from service, become disabled, die, for [[Required Minimum Distribution|RMDs]], or if/when the plan terminates.{{cite web| url=https://www.employeefiduciary.com/blog/401k-distribution-rules-frequently-asked-questions| title=401(k) Distribution Rules: Frequently Asked Questions for Employers and Employees| publisher=Employee Fiduciary| author=Eric Droblyen| date=May 6, 2025 |accessdate=September 1, 2025}} For example, many plans do not allow you to withdraw after you turn 59½ if you are still working, even though such withdrawals would be penalty-free. Plans ''may'' offer [[401(k)#In-service_distribution|In-service withdrawals]], [[#Hardship_distributions|hardship distributions]], and/or [[#Plan_loans|plan loans]] as ways to access money inside the plan. Plans are even allowed to [[401(k)#Involuntary_cash_out_distributions|involuntarily cash out]] accounts of former employees if the balance is small enough. Unlike employer plans, you are allowed to withdraw from an [[IRA]] at any time for any reason, with the tax treatment and any penalties being determined by IRS rules. Whether a withdrawal is advisable for your overall financial plan is a separate question. ===Hardship distributions=== Employer retirement plans ''may'', but are not required to, allow employees to withdraw money from plans before age 59½ for financial hardships, defined as an immediate and heavy financial need, and you are only allowed to withdraw the amount necessary to satisfy that need.{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/retirement-plans/plan-participant-employee/retirement-topics-hardship-distributions| title=Retirement topics - Hardship distributions| publisher=IRS| accessdate=August 27, 2025}} Such withdrawals ''may be'' subject to early withdrawal penalties if one of the exceptions does not apply. ===Plan loans=== Some employer plans offer a [[401(k)#Early_withdrawals_and_loans|loan feature]], which allows you to borrow money from the plan and repay it within five years, with interest, through payroll deductions. The loan amount is limited to 50% of your balance or $50,000, whichever is less. Unlike contributions, interest payments are not tax-deductible but are later taxable when you withdraw. If you don't pay the loan back for any reason, it will be considered a distribution and you will owe taxes and a 10% penalty on the loan balance. If you separate from your employer, you have until your tax filing deadline (with extensions) for that tax year to completely pay the loan back. While a plan loan can be convenient and relatively low-impact way to temporarily get money out of your plan, they have significant risks and are best reserved for emergencies only. ===457(b) plans=== {{Main|457(b)}} There are two types of 457(b) plans: governmental and non-governmental. Despite the similarity in name, they are very different. A governmental 457(b) behaves similarly to a 401(k) or 403(b), whereas a non-governmental 457(b) behaves more like a private deferred compensation plan. Contributions to and earnings within either type of 457(b) never have any early withdrawal penalties, but there are some considerations for early withdrawals for each. Governmental 457(b) plans are allowed to accept incoming rollovers from non-457(b) accounts. However, the plan must segregate non-457(b) money, and any non-457(b) money you withdraw early is subject to a penalty if an exception doesn't apply. If you have a 457(b) plan that has received rollovers from other types of accounts, consult with your plan administrator on the details of early withdrawal. Non-governmental 457(b) plans are only allowed to accept incoming rollovers from other non-governmental 457(b)s, so withdrawals are always penalty-free. Even though 457(b) money has no early withdrawal penalties, you should still make sure the distribution options fit within your plan. Governmental 457(b) plans have strict rules that generally prevent withdrawals while you're still employed at the plan sponsor. Once you leave that employer, governmental 457(b) plans usually have flexible distribution rules that allow for lump sum and installment distributions. Distribution options for non-governmental 457(b) plans are specific to a plan and are often very restrictive, sometimes to the point of it not making sense to use the plan in the first place. ===Roth accounts=== [[Roth IRA|Roth IRAs]] allow contributions to be withdrawn at any time tax- and penalty-free. The Roth IRA [[Roth_IRA#Distributions|distribution rules]] specify that all lifetime contributions come out first. Next, any Roth conversions you have done come out in the order you did them, grouped by year, with the taxable portion of each conversion (or group of conversions) coming out before the non-taxable portion. Earnings within the Roth IRA come out last. While many of the above exceptions can waive the early withdrawal penalty for a Roth IRA, only disability and the first-time home buyer exception can waive both early penalties ''and'' taxes, and only when it has been at least 5 years since you have set up and contributed to a Roth IRA.{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-publication-590-b| title=IRS Publication 590-B: Distributions from Individual Retirement Arrangements (IRAs)| publisher=Internal Revenue Service| accessdate=September 1, 2025}} You can set up a [[Substantially equal periodic payments|SEPP]] from a Roth IRA, and it will waive the early withdrawal penalties, but it does ''not'' waive the taxes on any withdrawn gains. For this reason and others, pre-tax accounts tend to be the better choice for [[early retirement]]. If you withdraw from a designated Roth account (for example, a [[401(k)#Roth_401(k)|Roth 401(k)]]), the above exceptions will waive early withdrawal penalties, but the earnings that have accrued inside the account are still taxable until the account is ''qualified.'' The account becomes qualified when you have met the 5-year period of participation since your first contribution to this account, and you are either 59½ or disabled. For non-qualified withdrawals, earnings and basis are pro-rata; that is, each withdrawal is taken to be a mix of earnings and basis in the proportions that exist in the account at that time. If you do a [[Roth conversion]] and withhold taxes from the conversion, the withholding is treated as distribution, and you will owe a 10% early withdrawal penalty if you are under age 59½, unless the amount withheld is rolled over to a Roth IRA or back into the traditional IRA.[https://www.irs.gov/taxtopics/tc413 Topic no. 413, Rollovers from retirement plans | Internal Revenue Service] ===Self-employed retirement accounts=== [[Solo 401(k) plan|Solo 401(k)s]] and [[SEP|SEP-IRAs]] are commonly-used retirement accounts by self-employed (for example, independent contractor) investors, and have the same 10% penalty for early withdrawals before age 59½. Solo 401(k)s have the same exceptions as qualified employer plans, and SEP-IRAs have the same exceptions as IRAs; see [[#Retirement_accounts|above]]. [[SIMPLE IRA|SIMPLE IRAs]] have a 10% penalty for early withdrawals before age 59½, and the same exceptions as for an IRA, but this penalty increases to '''25%''' for withdrawals within the first two years of plan participation. This time period begins on the first day a contribution is deposited into your account.{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/retirement-plans/retirement-plans-faqs-regarding-simple-ira-plans| title=SIMPLE IRA plan FAQs| publisher=IRS| accessdate=August 27, 2025}} ==Health Savings Accounts (HSAs)== {{Main|Health savings account}} Health Savings Accounts (HSAs) have a '''20%''' early withdrawal penalty if you make a non-qualified withdrawal (that is, not for a qualified medical expenseQualified medical expenses are determined by [https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p502.pdf IRS Publication 502].) before age 65, ''and'' the withdrawal is taxable income. After age 65, the early withdrawal penalty no longer applies, but non-qualified withdrawals are taxable, so the account behaves similarly to a [[traditional IRA]] when used in this way. Qualified withdrawals are always tax- and penalty-free. You can access money from an HSA anytime tax- and penalty-free for current medical expenses, and also past medical expenses for which you have saved receipts, as long as you had an HSA at the time the expense was incurred. A [[Health_savings_account#During_working_years|common tactic]] is to defer reimbursement of medical expenses from an HSA to retirement years, leaving money inside to grow tax-deferred or tax-free, so you may have a large repository of past receipts you can use for withdrawals. It's usually better to take qualified HSA withdrawals before retirement account withdrawals; see: [[Retirement draw-down priority]]. Because significant future medical expenses are likely, especially later in life, it usually does not make sense to make taxable withdrawals unless you need the money and most other funding sources have been exhausted. Taking non-qualified withdrawals before age 65 incurs ''both'' taxes and the large 20% penalty, neither of which you would pay if you later withdrew the money for medical expenses, and so should only be used a last resort. ==Annuities== Annuities are a very broad class of financial products. Many types of annuities have a 10% early withdrawal penalty for withdrawals before age 59½, like [[#Retirement_accounts|retirement accounts]]. A similar list of exceptions is listed in [https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p575.pdf IRS Pub 575]. In addition to IRS-imposed early withdrawal penalties, many annuity contracts also have surrender charges that can be quite severe for early withdrawals. Before taking any withdrawals, make sure you understand your annuity's rules for withdrawals. ==Notes== {{Reflist| group="note"}} ==See also== *[[401(k)]] *[[403(b)]] *[[IRA]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Forum link| t=460229 | title=[Wiki] Proposed new retirement account pages - Rule of 55, Early Withdrawal |author=fyre4ce | date = Aug 29, 2025}} {{Retirement accounts}} [[Category:Employer provided retirement plans]]

page.title: Retirement account at a former employer

revision.text:
{{US|reason=irrelevant}}
When separating from an employer, former employees often face the question of what to do with money they have invested in that employer's workplace retirement plan (for example, a [[401(k)]], [[403(b)]], or [[457(b)]]). '''Retirement account at a former employer''' describes the options available to you.
Generally, the options are to [[IRA rollovers and transfers|roll over]] the money into a new plan, roll it out into an [[IRA]], or leave it in the old plan. The best choice depends on a variety of factors, including whether you are continuing to work or retiring.<ref group="note">[[IRA#Comparison to employer accounts|Comparison between IRAs and employer plans]] contains a comprehensive comparison of features offered by various plans.</ref>
==If you are still working==
===Option 1: Roll it into the new employer's plan===
For this to be an option, you must be eligible to participate in the plan, the plan must have the same tax type (for example, Roth) as the money you are rolling in, and the plan must accept incoming [[IRA rollovers and transfers|rollovers]] (many, but not all do).
Rolling money into the new employer's plan has the advantage of simplicity, especially if you will be contributing to the new plan. It gives you one less account to keep track of and potentially forget about, and makes managing investments and [[rebalancing]] easier.
The value of this option strongly depends on the quality of the new plan, particularly the fees and investment choices. It's not necessary for the plan to have many good funds; a [[Three-fund portfolio|good portfolio]] can be build around a few or even one good fund. But, [[Expense ratios|fees and expenses]], both within [[Mutual fund|mutual funds]] inside the plan, and possibly added on top of the fund fees, can [[How_much_do_you_lose_to_annual_fees_after_many_years%3F|heavily erode]] your long-term investment performance. See: [[#Investments_in_employer_plans|Investments in employer plans]] below.
If the new employer's plan is an [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Employee_Retirement_Income_Security_Act_of_1974 ERISA]-governed plan, there is also an [[asset protection]] benefit to rolling money in. Assets in ERISA plans get federal protection from creditors and bankruptcy. See: [[Asset_protection#Investing_in_a_401(k)|Asset protection in a 401(k)]].
Other potential benefits include: *If you plan to retire between ages 55 and 59½, any money you roll in can be withdrawn penalty-free thanks to the [[Rule of 55]]. *If the new employer's plan has a [[Early_withdrawal#Plan_loans|loan feature]], you can take a plan loan using rolled-in money. *If you might work past the age when [[Required Minimum Distribution|Required Minimum Distributions (RMDs)]] start (as of 2025, 73 or 75 for those not already facing RMDs), there is an advantage to rolling pre-tax money into your new employer's plan. RMDs are not required from employer plan accounts if you are still working.<ref group="note">This is true as long as you own less than 5% of the company. If you own at least 5% of the employer, RMDs are required once you reach RMD age, whether you are still working or not. Most commonly, this affects small business owners and investors with a [[Solo 401k|Solo 401(k)]].</ref> Because the US generally has [[Progressive tax|progressive]] tax rates, taking RMDs while also earning a substantial income can cause you to pay higher tax rates on those withdrawals than you would later.
If the new employer's plan has reasonable investments and low fees, this is an excellent option and should be the default choice for pre-tax (also known as "traditional") assets.
===Option 2: Roll it out into an IRA===
{{Quote |quote=[The IRA rollover market] is fraught with risks for you. You could pick the wrong product, pay too much in fees, or needlessly give up a standout 401(k)—all of which could add up to a less comfortable retirement. |source=—Ian Salisbury in [https://money.com/collection-post/why-rolling-over-401k-ira-important-retirement/ Why is rolling over my 401(k) such a big deal?], Money magazine, July 2014.}} You can always [[IRA rollovers and transfers|roll out]] money from a former employer into either a [[traditional IRA]] or [[Roth IRA]] (depending on the tax type of the money). It is easy to find IRAs with good investments and very low fees, so this not a concern like for an employer plan. The parameters of this option depend on whether the money is pre-tax or Roth, and you can make a separate decision for each tax type - for example, rolling pre-tax money into a new employer's plan, and rolling Roth money out into a Roth IRA.
Novice investors can be manipulated into purchasing inappropriate investments in an IRA by self-interested brokers, whereas in a 401(k) plan, even an expensive one, participants typically have some protection from poor investment choices. If rolling money out into an IRA, be very cautious of sales agents or financial advisors selling loaded mutual funds, complex products like [[Variable annuity|variable annuities]], or private investments. If you have any doubts about an investment, pay for a consult with a fee-only fiduciary [[Investment advisor|financial planner]] or ask on the [https://www.bogleheads.org/forum/index.php Bogleheads forum].
Rollover IRAs retain unlimited bankruptcy protection per federal law,<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.kiplinger.com/retirement/iras/is-your-ira-protected-in-bankruptcy| title=Is Your IRA Protected from Creditors in Bankruptcy? | publisher=Kiplinger| author=Donna Levalley| date=June 26, 2025| accessdate=September 2, 2025}}</ref> whereas contributory IRAs have a limit on the amount exempted from bankruptcy. Both rollover and contributory IRAs get [[Asset_protection#Investing_in_an_IRA|state-level protection]] from general creditor claims, which may be inferior to the protection of an ERISA employer plan but varies widely by state. This is one reason to keep rollover IRAs separate and not make any contributions to them - you need to be able to prove the rollover IRA monies are from the 401k.
====Pre-tax money====
Rolling out pre-tax money into a traditional IRA has the disadvantage that it interferes with the [[Backdoor Roth|Backdoor Roth IRA]] process, making it not work as intended. If your income makes you ineligible for direct contribution to a Roth IRA, or even if this could happen in the foreseeable future, and you want the ability to contribute to a Roth IRA, that is a clear disadvantage of rolling pre-tax money out into an IRA.
If the amount of pre-tax money is relatively small (maybe a few $10,000s or less) and you want to preserve the ability to make Backdoor Roth IRA contributions, and none of the other options are good, you could consider [[Roth conversion|converting]] the money to a Roth IRA. The converted amount becomes taxable income in that year, but the money will be tax-free going forward. Though it might not be the optimal mathematical decision, it would get the money into a good account and simplify things, and that has value.
If you have a large pre-tax balance, converting it all to a Roth IRA is usually a poor tax planning decision, as you will likely pay a lower rate withdrawing that money in retirement, given that the conversion income will stack on top of your earned income this year and the US has a [[Progressive tax|progressive]] tax system. But, if you expect your tax rate to be unusually low - for example, if you separate from your employer early in the year and take a lot of time off between jobs - it could make sense to convert a larger balance to Roth. Taxable Roth conversions are a complex tax planning decision.
If you roll pre-tax money out into a [[rollover IRA]], it is best practice to not make any ''contributions'' into that IRA. If you wish to make IRA contributions, open a separate IRA account and contribute there. Some employer plans will only accept incoming rollovers from rollover IRAs that have not had contributions, and if you later decide to roll money into an employer plan, keeping rollover money separate will avoid this problem. It may also have asset protection benefits.
====Roth money====
Rolling Roth money from an employer plan into a [[Roth IRA]] is usually the best choice. Roth IRAs always allow contributions to be withdrawn tax- and penalty-free at any time, and any contributions you made into the old employer's designated Roth account also count toward this amount. Therefore, in an emergency, having easier access to that money is a clear advantage. There is also a general benefit to having money in an account that you control, versus your employer.
There are a few potential disadvantages to rolling employer plan money into a Roth IRA, the main one being [[asset protection]]. Check the asset protection laws in your state to see how much protection they give to Roth IRAs versus the old employer's plan, which likely gets ERISA protection. Also consider that you might later move to a state that gives Roth IRAs less protection. Another potential disadvantage is if the old employer's plan has unusually good investments; see [[#Investments_in_employer_plans|Investments in employer plans]] below.
Rolling employer plan money into a Roth IRA is not reversible; the IRS does not allow rollovers from a Roth IRA into a employer plan's designated Roth account.<ref>[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/rollover_chart.pdf IRS Rollover Chart]</ref>
===Option 3: Leave it in the old employer's plan===
Leaving money in the old employer's plan is always an option, except if the balance is so small that they can involuntarily roll the money out into an IRA (less than $7,000) or cash it out (less than $1,000).<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-publication-560| title=Publication 560 (2024), Retirement Plans for Small Business | publisher=Internal Revenue Service| accessdate=September 2, 2025}}</ref>
A downside of leaving money in the employer's plan is that you have one more account to keep track of and possibly forget. It makes managing your investments more complicated.
Another downside is that there may be unforeseen circumstances which will result in difficulties obtaining your funds at a later time. For example, the company may go out of business, be resold, or not keep adequate records. While you are legally entitled to your funds, the practicality of these unplanned situations can result in significant delays or nonpayment. For these reasons, many people recommended to not leave your 401(k) money with a former employer.<ref>{{forum link| t=57457| title=401(k) Vesting Dispute - Need Advice| date=July 9, 2010}}</ref>
Consider the fees and investment choices in the old plan. If it has high fees, that would be a strong reason to roll the money out. The old plan could have unusual investments with lower fees and/or could be uniquely valuable compared to what you can get in an IRA; see: [[#Investments_in_employer_plans|Investments in employer plans]] below.
If the old plan has a loan feature, you generally cannot take a plan loan after you separate from service.
If the old plan is a governmental [[457(b)]], it has no early (that is, before age 55 or 59½) withdrawal penalties. This benefit is lost if you roll the money out into an IRA or into a non-457(b) workplace plan. If you think there's a chance you will want to access the money early, that would be a compelling reason to leave money in a governmental 457(b).
Nonetheless, if there are issues with the other options, leaving money in an old employer's plan can be worth this extra complexity and risk. Most commonly, this would occur when you have a large pre-tax balance, the new employer's plan isn't great (or doesn't accept incoming rollovers), and you wish to make [[Backdoor Roth|Backdoor Roth IRA]] contributions.
===Option 4: Start a business and roll it into a Solo 401(k)===
{{Warning|Starting a business and opening a Solo 401(k) are complex tasks with many opportunities for costly mistakes, which financial novices should not attempt on their own.}}
If you start a business (or already have one) and open a [[Solo 401(k) plan|Solo 401(k)]] that accepts incoming rollovers, you can roll over money from the old employer's plan into the Solo 401(k). Two clear advantages of this option are that pre-tax money in a Solo 401(k) does not interfere with the [[Backdoor Roth|Backdoor Roth IRA]] process, and it's easy to find free or inexpensive Solo 401(k) plans with good investments and low fees.
However, this process is much more complex than the other options:
*You must have a legitimate business, meaning an activity that you '''intend to do regularly and for profit'''. If you end up deciding to discontinue the business after some time, that’s OK. But if it’s obviously a sham business, you run a huge risk – the IRS can forcibly dissolve it and your Solo 401k, making you pay income tax and penalties on all the money you have in there. *You may need to get a business license from your local government and/or some kind of permit at the federal or state level *You have to actually earn a profit in the year you want to open the plan, though there’s no limit on how small it can be (for example, $10). *Get an EIN (employer identification number) from the IRS. This is free and easy. *Open a Solo 401k ('''not''' a [[SEP|SEP-IRA]]) that accepts incoming rollovers. Most, but not all, of the free plans accept incoming rollovers. *If/when you have more than $250,000 in the plan, you have to file a [https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-form-5500-ez Form 5500-EZ] every year to report the plan’s assets and some other details. It’s free and can be done online, but the penalties for failing to file are enormous.
If your business has employees other than your spouse, you would need to open a "real" (non-Solo) [[401(k)]]. But, if that plan accepts incoming rollovers it would function in the same way as as a Solo 401(k).
Depending on the state you live in, there may be additional fees or taxes to set up and maintain a business, and these would have to be weighted against the benefits of this option.
Going through all this trouble just to create a better home for your pre-tax retirement money will not be worth it for most investors. This option is only recommended for someone who is a hobbyist and likes getting into the details of this stuff, ''and'' has an idea for a legitimate business that would pass an IRS audit.
===Option 5: Cash it out===
This is usually advisable only if you need the money immediately. Not only will you forfeit tax-advantaged growth, but you will pay taxes on the distribution. There may also be a 10% penalty if you are under age 59½, unless the plan is with an employer from whom you retired in or after the year you reached age 55.
==When you are retired==
When you retire, the choices are simpler. Many of the parameters are the same as when working, although there are a few additional things to consider.
===Option 1: Roll it out into an IRA===
When retiring, rolling both pre-tax and Roth money from an employer into traditional and Roth IRAs is usually the right choice. Advantages are that you get a wide variety of investment choices and low fees in an account under your complete control. Employers can change their plan terms and investment options, or add fees. Though less common, employers can lose records, go out of business, or be bought out, all of which can complicate you getting access to your money. In rare cases, employers or people working for them have stolen plan money. The risk of serious problems is low, but there is a general advantage to removing an employer from the picture.
Consolidating all your retirement assets into one or two IRAs of each tax type makes investment management, [[rebalancing]], and [[Required Minimum Distribution|Required Minimum Distributions (RMDs)]] simpler. See also: [[Required_Minimum_Distribution#Combining_distributions_from_multiple_accounts|Combining RMDs from multiple accounts]].
===Option 2: Leave it in the old employer's plan===
While rolling money out into an IRA when retiring should be the default choice, there are several reasons why it might be better to leave money in an employer plan. These reasons include:
*The plan may have ultra-low fee funds and/or uniquely valuable investments compared to what you can get in an IRA; see [[#Investments_in_employer_plans|Investments in employer plans]] *If you are retiring before age 59½, but in or after the year you turn 55, you can withdraw money from the plan penalty-free by way of the [[Rule of 55]]. *If the plan is a governmental [[457(b)]], it has no early withdrawal penalties. If there's a chance you will want to access the money before age 59½, that would be an advantage for leaving money in the 457(b). *Especially if it's an ERISA plan, the employer plan probably has better [[asset protection]] than an IRA.
====Solo 401(k)====
If you are retiring with a [[Solo 401(k) plan|Solo 401(k)]], the parameters are different than choosing to leave money in a large-employer plan. A Solo 401(k) behaves more like an IRA; as you are the employer, you have a similarly high degree of control over the account, and no risks of issues (like the employer being bought out) that could interfere with your access to the money.
You are generally allowed to leave a business open even if you are not earning any income, as long as there is a potential for future income. However, your state may charge taxes or fees for keeping the business open, and you may have costs for maintaining the plan. If the Solo 401(k) has more than $250,000 in assets, you have to file an annual Form 5500-EZ. For these reasons, if it's likely you won't be earning more income, rolling the money out into an IRA is usually the best option.
==Less common situations==
There are some less common situations that can affect the parameters of the choices above. Retirement account rules are complex, and this is a non-exhaustive list.
*Rarely, employer plans will allow incoming rollovers even for employees who have separated. If you have a former employer plan like this, that adds an additional option to the decision. *[[Roth conversion|Roth conversions]] from a traditional IRA are always allowed, but many employer plans don't allow Roth conversions of pre-tax money inside the plan. If you might want to do Roth conversions while working - this is often undesirable because conversion income will stack on top of your earned income, and tax rates are progressive, though exceptional cases exist - and the available employer plans do not allow in-plan Roth rollovers, then there is an advantage to leaving some pre-tax money in an IRA. *One benefit of a [[Solo 401(k) plan|Solo 401(k)]] over an IRA is that they are not subject to Unrelated Debt Financed Income (UDFI) on leveraged real estate investments.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irafinancial.com/blog/understanding-the-udfi-exception-for-solo-401k-real-estate-investors/| title=Understanding The UDFI Exception for Solo 401(k) Real Estate Investors| publisher=IRAFinancial| date=July 16, 2025| accessdate=August 26, 2025}}</ref> This would only be an issue for a custom Solo 401(k) plan where you are directly investing in real estate. If you are, this would be an advantage for leaving money in the Solo 401(k), even if there are annual costs for keeping the plan open.
==Investments in employer plans==
Employer plans only offer a set of investments selected by the plan provider, usually in the range of one to several dozen options. They may include some good fund choices, but some or all could be high-fee actively managed funds. These choices contrast with IRAs, which have an enormous range of options, including stocks, bonds, mutual funds, ETFs, CDs, Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs), and even some derivatives.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.schwab.com/learn/story/trading-options-retirement-account| title=What Options Strategies Are Allowed in an IRA?| publisher=Charles Schwab| date=August 13, 2025| accessdate=September 12, 2025}}</ref> Historically, employer plans have commonly had high fees, both inside the funds and sometimes added on top of the fund expenses. [[403(b)]] plans have been notorious for offering high-fee annuities. For these reasons, in the past many financial experts have recommended by default that you should roll employer plan money out into an IRA when you separate from the employer.
However, employer plan fees have come down in recent decades, particularly at larger employers. Many plans now include low-fee [[index fund]] choices and have only small or no additional fees paid by the participants. And, the [[Bogleheads® investment philosophy]] does not require a large number of funds to build a good portfolio; [[Three-fund portfolio|three good funds]] should be plenty, and if you have assets other places (spouse's plan, IRAs, [[Taxable account|brokerage]], etc.), a portfolio can be build around a plan with only one good fund. Therefore, rolling former employer plan money into an IRA should no longer be the default choice, even though it will be the right choice in some situations - especially with [[#Roth_money|Roth money]].
Some employer plans may even offer ''better'' investments that can be purchased in an IRA, or unusual investments that might be valuable to certain investors. Example may include:
*Ultra-low fee "institutional-class" funds - though in practice this benefit may be negligible or non-existent; see [[#Expense_ratios|below]] *[[Collective Investment Trusts]], which may have substantially lower fees than their retail investment counterparts *A [[stable value fund]], purportedly offering bond-like returns with cash-like risk *Private investments, such as real estate funds *Annuities - While many employer plans have historically had only poor-quality high-fee annuities, more now have better annuities. If you are in the market for an annuity and your employer plan offers annuities that are as good or even better than what you can get on the retail market, that could be a good reason to leave money in an employer plan. *An [[Employee Stock Ownership Plan|Employee Stock Ownership Plan (ESOP)]], allowing appreciated stock to be withdrawn and gains to be taxed at lower long-term capital gains tax rates using [[net unrealized appreciation]]
===Expense ratios===
Some employer plans leverage economies of scale and offer funds with lower expense ratios, based on the larger asset base available within the plan. For example, the Vanguard Institutional Plus Index Fund [https://investor.vanguard.com/investment-products/mutual-funds/profile/VIIIX VIIIX] (an S&P 500 index fund) has a 0.02% expense ratio, compared to its retail counterparts [https://investor.vanguard.com/investment-products/mutual-funds/profile/VFIAX VFIAX] and [https://investor.vanguard.com/investment-products/etfs/profile/voo VOO], which have 0.04% and 0.03% expense ratios respectively. The practical difference is quite small - $10 or $20 per year per $100,000 invested - and is unlikely to make a meaningful difference in your investing performance, but is not completely worthless.
Also note that Fidelity offers S&P 500 and total US stock market index funds, [https://fundresearch.fidelity.com/mutual-funds/summary/315911750 FXAIX] and [https://fundresearch.fidelity.com/mutual-funds/summary/315911693 FSKAX], with 0.015% expense ratios. Schwab and iShares also offer a variety of funds with expense ratios in this range. At these tiny levels of fees, other factors like how accurately the fund tracks the index, which and how many stocks are in the index, and (if in a [[taxable account]]) small differences in [[Tax-efficient fund placement|tax efficiency]], can have a larger impact than these fee differences.
As of 2025, both [[Fidelity]] and [[E*TRADE]] offer zero-fee mutual funds, which can be purchased inside an IRA. Fidelity's zero-fee funds have been around for a few years, and the data do show a very small benefit in total return compared to low-fee index funds like those from Vanguard. Commentators have raised concerns over a possibly lower tax efficiency,<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.whitecoatinvestor.com/expense-ratios/| title=Does Expense Ratio Really Matter?| publisher=White Coat Investor| date=August 6, 2018| accessdate=September 12, 2025}}</ref> and also a lack of portability to another broker, but neither of these are problems for IRA investments. The bottom line is that while ultra-low fee funds are nice, very low or zero-fee options also exist for IRAs, and any differences are too small to be meaningful.

The '''[[Thrift Savings Plan]]''' offers participants five '''Lifecycle''' funds containing a mix of the TSP's five core funds. The Lifecycle funds are [[Target date retirement funds]], with the same expenses as the other TSP funds. == Composition == === Glide path === The charts and data below, one separate tabs of the embedded spreadsheet, show the [[Glide paths|glide path]] of the Lifecycle funds, using data as of January 18, 2018.[https://www.tsp.gov/investmentfunds/lfundsheet/fundPerformance_L.shtml Lifecycle Fund Performance] at https://www.tsp.gov as of 18 January 2018. Readers are encouraged to visit the TSP site for up-to-date compositions of the Lifecycle Funds. General themes of the Lifecycle funds glide path: * The glide paths shift toward bond funds over the years, as expected. * Within the bonds allocations, the allocation shifts more toward G Fund and away from the F Fund as retirement age is reached. * Within the US equity allocation, there is a slight shift from the S Fund (small cap) toward the C Fund (large cap) as retirement age is reached. * The US to International equity ratio stays at 70:30 through the entire glide path. The various tabs (click each tab's hyperlink to view) depict: * '''TSP Lifecycle Glide Path''' - Illustrates how each decade, the holdings in the three equity funds gradually decline, while the G Fund steadily climbs until the G Fund becomes 74% of the holdings when the Income phase is reached. The sky blue line labeled '''Equity''' shows the overall equity percentage of each fund (C Fund + S Fund + I Fund). * '''Glide Path''' - displays the equity percentage (C Fund + S Fund + I Fund) of each Lifecycle fund, starting in year 2018 (representing the L 2050 fund) through the 40 years ending with the L Income fund. Note that the data points are in ten-year intervals, so the actual glide path is a gentler slope. For comparison, [[Vanguard target retirement funds | Vanguard Target Retirement Date funds]] and Fidelity Freedom Funds of the same year are shown. * '''Fixed Income Glide Path''' - Many TSP investors question how much G Fund to hold relative to the F Fund and other fixed income assets. This decision can be informed by the prescribed holdings of the G Fund and F Fund in the Lifecycle funds, relative to the investor's point in time in their investment lifetime. The chart on this tab shows how in the Lifecycle fund, the F Fund starts at 6 percent for the youngest investor, and stays at almost that same percentage all the way through retirement age. By comparison, the G Fund starts out with an allocation nearly double the F Fund and then climbs steadily over the decades, increasingly so over the five years before the "Income" year is reached. * '''Fixed Income as Percentage''' - shows the relative holdings of the G Fund and F Fund and compares their relative weights as the two components of the fixed income portion of the portfolio, across the decades of the Lifecycle funds. The F Fund proportion starts out as roughly one-third of the overall fixed income allocation, and steadily decreases over the years. * '''US Stocks as Percentage''' - shows the relative holdings of the C Fund and S Fund and compares their relative weights across the decades of the Lifecycle funds. There is a slight shift toward C Fund (large-cap) and away from S Fund (small-cap) as the glide path goes from the younger investor toward retirement income phase. * '''US vs International''' - shows that the US equity (C Fund + S Fund) to International equity (I Fund) ratio stays constant at 70:30 for all Lifecycle funds. {| class="wikitable" |+ Table. TSP Lifecycle Fund glide path |- | {{#widget:Google Spreadsheet |key=19loE4Tto2c_dXf2fbqqZq8yjKO2Dg7RjGdftueOkMI0 |width=800 |height=540 }}
{{spreadsheet|key=19loE4Tto2c_dXf2fbqqZq8yjKO2Dg7RjGdftueOkMI0}} | |} Note that these curves were auto-created by Google Spreadsheets. A more careful look at the glide path reveals that the rise in G Fund, and the attendant decline in the other four funds, occurs more dramatically in the final five years before the the Income level arrives, than is depicted in the smoother blue line in the chart. Also, be aware that the data points in these spreadsheet are separated by ten years; the lines between the data points in this graph are "straighter" than they truly are in real life. In real life the lines will be smoother. == Role in portfolio == TSP investors considering a Lifecycle fund should consider the same questions that investors in any target date retirement fund must weigh. See [[Target date retirement funds]] for a review of these general considerations. Issues of concern to TSP investors in particular include: * The fact that the [[I Fund]] is not a complete international fund may lead some investors to not use the Lifecycle fund in favor of using individual funds and holding the international allocation outside the TSP. This concern will become moot in 2018 or 2019 because on December 6, 2017, the TSP's governing board "at its most recent meeting accepted a recommendation by a consultant to switch to linking the I Fund to the [[MSCI]] All Country World Index, which covers non-U.S. developed markets, smaller companies and emerging markets."{{Cite web | title = TSP to Change I Fund Index, Leave Others as Is | publisher = FEDweek | date = 2017-12-06 | accessdate = 2017-12-08 | url = http://www.fedweek.com/fedweek/tsp-change-fund-index-leave-others/ | quote = The board at its most recent meeting accepted a recommendation by a consultant to switch to linking the I Fund to the MSCI All Country World Index, which covers non-U.S. developed markets, smaller companies and emerging markets.}}{{Forum link|t=233929|title=Thrift Savings Plan to Change I Fund Index|date=December 7, 2017}} The change could take a year or more to implement. * The TSP Lifecycle funds employ an active investing approach for setting the funds' glide paths, which is based on efficient frontier analysis using capital market assumptions over a 20-year time horizon and stochastic modeling projections for inflation, economic growth, salary growth, corporate profits, P/E rations, interest rates, and exchange rates.See: {{cite web| url=https://www.frtib.gov/pdf/minutes/MM-2016Nov-Att6.pdf| title=Thrift Savings Plan Lifecycle Fund Asset Allocation| publisher=Mercer| date=November 2016}}{{dead link}} Investors looking for a passive approach may want to use individual funds and look to Vanguard, Fidelity, or another large fund family for examples of target date glide paths. ==Notes== {{Reflist|group="note"}} == See also == * [[Target date retirement funds]] * [[Glide paths]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [https://www.tsp.gov/investmentfunds/lfundsheet/fundPerformance_L.shtml Lifecycle Funds] at [https://www.tsp.gov/index.html Thrift Savings Plan] {{TSP}} {{Balanced funds|state = collapsed}} [[Category:Thrift Savings Plan]] [[Category:Balanced funds]]

The '''{{PAGENAME}}''' (International Stock Index Investment Fund) is one of six investment offerings inside the [[Thrift Savings Plan]], a contributory retirement program for United States federal employees, members of the uniformed services, and their beneficiaries.
==Fundamentals== The I Fund is an international developed market stock [[Collective Investment Trusts|collective investment trust]].<ref group="note"> Technically, the I Fund is a collective investment trust. The main practical differences between a collective investment trust and a mutual fund are: # A collective investment trust has no ticker. An investor gets performance information about the fund from the fund administrator through performance reports and fact sheets. # A collective investment trust does not distribute dividends or capital gains, but accumulates these incomes in the fund [[Net asset value| net asset value]].
The I Fund's collective trust manager is BlackRock Institutional Trust Company, N.A. For more information regarding collective trusts, see [[Collective Investment Trusts]] </ref> The fund tracks the MSCI ACWI IMI ex USA ex China ex Hong Kong Index, which covers the stock markets of twenty-one developed countries and twenty-three emerging markets.
On December 6, 2017, the TSP's governing board "at its most recent meeting accepted a recommendation by a consultant to switch to linking the I Fund to the [[MSCI]] All Country World Index, which covers non-U.S. developed markets, smaller companies and emerging markets."<ref name="fedw_TSPt">{{Cite web | title = TSP to Change I Fund Index, Leave Others as Is | author = | publisher = FEDweek | date = 2017-12-06 | accessdate = 2017-12-08 | url = http://www.fedweek.com/fedweek/tsp-change-fund-index-leave-others/ | quote = The board at its most recent meeting accepted a recommendation by a consultant to switch to linking the I Fund to the MSCI All Country World Index, which covers non-U.S. developed markets, smaller companies and emerging markets.}}</ref><ref>{{Forum post|t=233929|title=Thrift Savings Plan to Change I Fund Index|date=December 7, 2017}}</ref> In the November 28, 2017 meeting of the TSP Governing Board, it was stated: "The target date for the change would be some time in 2019,"<ref>{{Cite web|author=Federal Retirement Thrift Investment Board|date=|title=Minutes of the Meeting of the Federal Retirement Thrift Investment Board Members, November 24, 2017|url=https://minutes.frtib.gov/meeting_minutes/2017/2017Nov.zip|accessdate=|publisher=frtib.gov|type=ZIP}}</ref> although the TSP stated at the end of 2018 that the switch would occur in the second half of 2020, due to timelines related to the assignment of a new fund manager contract for the TSP funds.<ref name="frti_">{{Cite web|author=Federal Retirement Thrift Investment Board|date=2018-12-27|title=Minutes of the Meeting of the Federal Retirement Thrift Investment Board Members, December 27, 2108|url=https://minutes.frtib.gov/meeting_minutes/2018/2018Dec.zip|access-date=|publisher=frtib.gov|type=ZIP|quote=Lastly, [TSP CIO] Mr. McCaffrey stated the multi-manager effort, as it is known, includes the I Fund. This means two things: 1) FRTIB will suspend previously announced plans for the re-competition of the I Fund on a single manager basis because that effort will be bundled with the multi-manager initiative. 2) The second issue is that the planned transition of the I Fund benchmark from the MSCI EAFE Index to the MSCI ACWI ex-US IMI Index was intended to be assigned with the new I Fund manager contract. That benchmark change will continue to await the assignment of a new primary manager for the I Fund. As a result, the benchmark transition should be concluded within 6 months of the new contract award, meaning the second half of 2020.}}</ref><ref name="pion_Forl">{{Cite web |title=For largest U.S. retirement fund, the sky's the limit |author=Brian Croce | publisher=Pensions & Investments |access-date=13 February 2019 |url= https://www.pionline.com/article/20190204/PRINT/190209965/for-largest-us-retirement-fund-the-skys-the-limit|quote=By the end of 2019, the [Federal Retirement Thrift Investment] board will issue a request for proposal seeking two investment managers to manage a portion of each of the index funds, according to Kim Weaver, director of external affairs, [...] 'and a decision will be reached sometime in 2020', she added. Once the managers are selected, a change will be made to the TSP's I Fund — one of the index funds that invests in international equities — to incorporate emerging markets, Ms. Weaver said.}}</ref>
At its May 13, 2020 meeting the Federal Retirement Thrift Investment Board unanimously passed a motion to delay, pending further study, the implementation of the I Fund benchmark change to the MSCI ACWI ex US Investible Market Index from the MSCI EAFE Index. The stated rationale was “the meaningful different economic environment related in large part to the impact of the global Covid-19 pandemic, as well as the nomination of 3 new FRTIB Board members.”<ref>{{Forum link|title=Re: Wiki - Approximating total international stock market - update for TSP|p=5897382|author=MichDad|date=March 22, 2021}} and {{cite web|date=May 13, 2020|title=Minutes of the Meeting of the Board Members|url=https://minutes.frtib.gov/meeting_minutes/2020/2020May30.zip|access-date=|publisher=Federal Retirement Thrift Investment Board|type=ZIP}}</ref>
As of July 31, 2024, the I Fund benchmark has been updated to the MSCI ACWI IMI ex USA ex China ex Hong Kong Index.<ref>{{Cite web | title = Thrift Savings Plan I Fund International Stock Index Investment Fund | author=The Thrift Savings Plan|publisher=tsp.gov | date = 2024-09-03 | accessdate = 2024-09-10 | url = https://www.tsp.gov/funds-individual/i-fund}}</ref>
==Role in a portfolio== The MSCI ACI IMI ex USA ex China ex Hong Kong Index includes 5000+ stocks from 21 developed markets and 23 emerging markets.
The 21 developed markets are those in the [[MSCI EAFE index|MSCI EAFE]] index minus Hong Kong plus Canada. The 23 emerging markets match the offering in the MSCI ACWI IMI ex USA index minus China.
The index includes large, mid, and small caps. It covers approximately 99% of global market cap minus the USA, China, and Hong Kong.
TSP investors seeking to round out the gaps in the I Fund can consider the following: * Supplement with iShares MSCI China ETF (MCHI): 0.59% expense ratio as of October 13, 2024.<ref>{{Cite web | title = iShares MSCI China ETF | author=iShares by Blackrock|publisher=ishares.com | date = 2024-10-11 | accessdate = 2024-10-13 | url = https://www.ishares.com/us/products/239619/ishares-msci-china-etf}}</ref>
Or, they can place all of their international investments with Vanguard (for example, in the [{{Vf | 0113}} Vanguard Total International Stock Market Fund]).

{{Expand article}} The [[Thrift Savings Plan]] is regulated by most of the same rules as [[Employee Retirement Income Security Act]] (ERISA) plans like [[401(k)]]s. The IRS explains what plans ''may'' do, must do, and may not do. A plan may not do what it is not allowed to do by the IRS, and a plan is not required to do what it may do. This page examines some of the contrasts between the TSP and 401(k) plans in general.
Although the TSP currently has less flexibility in some areas compared to some 401(k) plans, the Federal Retirement Thrift Investment Board is examining rules changes that could offer participants more options such as in-plan Roth conversions.<ref>{{Forum link | t=140180 |title=Improving the TSP for current participants|date=24 November 2017}}</ref>
== Contrasts == === In-plan Roth conversions === While [[401(k)]] plans with a traditional and Roth option ''may'' allow in-plan conversions from traditional to Roth, the TSP does not. As of November 2013, the TSP is studying the idea of permitting in-plan Roth conversions and has listed this as an initiative for further action in 2014.<ref>{{forum link| t=131963 |title=Possible TSP Changes| date=January 30, 2014}}, with a link to Federal Retirement Thrift Investment Board's November 2013 minutes.</ref> A communication from the TSP in August, 2014, indicated further progress in this effort.<ref>{{Forum link| p=2158467 | title=Improving the TSP for current participants | date=August 17, 2014}}</ref>
=== Partial withdrawals === Prior to the enactment of the [[TSP Modernization Act of 2017]], the TSP allowed separated employees to make a single lifetime [[TSP_withdrawals#Partial|partial withdrawal]], for example to a traditional or Roth [[IRA]]. With the act now implemented, both current and separated employees may make multiple partial withdrawals
=== Incoming rollovers into the plan === {{See also|TSP transfers and rollovers}} The IRS permits employer sponsored retirement to allow participants to roll over certain eligible accounts into the plan, such as IRAs or 401(k)s from previous jobs. While these plans are ''permitted'' to offer this option, they are not required to, and many 401(k) plans have different rules on whether a participant is allowed to roll over an account into their 401(k) plan. Additionally, while most plans will allow current employees to roll over assets into the plan, many plans will not allow former employees to do so.
The TSP allows both current and separated employees to roll over traditional pre-tax IRAs and eligible employer plans into their TSP accounts.
Only Roth 401(k)s can be rolled into the Roth TSP; Roth IRAs may not be. This restriction applies to employer plans in general, and not just the TSP, as described in [[IRA_rollovers_and_transfers#Roth_IRA| IRA Rollovers and Transfers - Roth IRA]].
Note that direct beneficiaries (a surviving person who inherited a TSP account from their spouse and chose to stay in the TSP) cannot roll over or transfer money into a beneficiary TSP account; see [[TSP estate planning]] for more.
=== Beneficiaries === {{main|TSP estate planning}} There are some important considerations in how the TSP handles beneficiaries compared to what eligible plans may or may not offer. See linked page for more details.
=== Mutual fund window ===
Many retirement plans offer participants the option to invest their assets in a [[Self directed brokerage account|self-directed brokerage window]] that would offer a wider selection of investment options than just the core TSP funds. The TSP now has a [[Thrift_Savings_Plan#Mutual_fund_window|mutual fund window]], allowing investments in mutual funds, but not stocks or ETFs. The window is also limited to 25% of the TSP balance, and with high fees.

{{US}} Participants in the Federal [[Thrift Savings Plan]] (TSP) have two options for withdrawing from a TSP account after leaving federal service. Participants can take '''{{PAGENAME}}''' as a partial withdrawal or a full withdrawal. Either type of withdrawal is now done on the TSP web site. {{401k rollover infobox}} The Thrift Savings Plan has been described as "easily the best retirement plan in the country"{{cite web| url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/thrift-savings-plan-the-model-for-all-401k-plans/| title=Thrift Savings Plan - The Model for all 401(k) Plans!| publisher=CBS News| author=Allan Roth| author-link=Allan Roth| date=May 16, 2010}} by Bogleheads® author [[Allan Roth]]. Therefore, investors should think carefully before closing their TSP which can be an irrevocable decision.{{cite web| url=https://www.tsp.gov/keepingscore/| title=Keeping Score?| publisher=TSP.gov}}{{cite web| url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NINMboa0mUM| title=Thinking about moving your TSP savings to another plan?| publisher=YouTube, from TSP4gov}}{{Cite web | title = As brokers urge IRA rollovers, ex-workers ditch their low-fee federal retirement plan | publisher = Washington Post | url-access=subscription | date = 2014-08-16 | accessdate = 2017-12-10 | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/as-brokers-urge-ira-rollovers-ex-workers-ditch-their-low-fee-federal-retirement-plan/2014/08/14/53c68dd0-2239-11e4-958c-268a320a60ce_story.html?utm_term=.6a70c414e337}}{{cite web| url=https://www.fedsmith.com/2008/07/30/seeking-access-tsps-billions/| title=Seeking Access to the TSP’s Billions| publisher=FedSmith.com}} == Withdrawal options == {{Quotation|1=[A]nyone who’s proposing that you leave the TSP and move your money to an individual retirement account has some serious explaining to do. The investment industry is doing and saying anything it can to get at your TSP account, and it’s not your benefit it has in mind. I urge you to resist the temptation to believe there is some better solution to the problem of saving and investing for retirement. There is not. At 2.5 basis points per year [3.8 as of 2017] — those are one-hundredths of a percent — the TSP is the envy of private-sector investors and kryptonite to brokers, bankers and insurance agents. Make the most of the TSP, and you’ll reap the rewards. Fall for the sales pitch, and you’ll pay the price — literally.|author=Mike Miles|title=[http://money.federaltimes.com/2013/02/04/dont-overlook-tsp-for-lowest-cost-investment/ Don’t overlook TSP for lowest-cost investment]|source=Federal Times}} See: [https://www.tsp.gov/planparticipation/withdrawals/withdrawingAccount.shtml TSP Withdrawals] at TSP.gov. Also, this article's [[Talk:TSP withdrawals|Discussion tab]] for a discussion of withdrawals for non-Roth accounts. === Partial === Since the enactment of the [[TSP Modernization Act of 2017]] on November 23, 2017, participants are no longer limited to a single partial withdrawal in their lifetime. Even while still employed, participants may make up to four withdrawals per year.{{cite web| url=https://www.tsp.gov/publications/tspbk12.pdf| title=TSP: In-Service Withdrawals}} Withdrawals can be taken from Traditional balances only, Roth balances only, or pro rata from both. Withdrawals are always distributed pro rata from the TSP funds, but this can be mitigated by doing an interfund transfer to restore the correct allocation. If you want to withdraw from the G Fund only, you can make your withdrawal, which will take some amount from the stock funds, then do an interfund transfer to move money from the G Fund back to the stock funds. === Full === Full withdrawals can be made as a single payment, life annuity, or as a series of monthly payments, which can be a specific dollar amount or based on life expectancy. Any combination of these three options may be used.{{cite web| url=https://www.tsp.gov/publications/tspbk25.pdf| title=TSP: Distributions}} If the payments are a fixed dollar Aaount, the amount can be changed. If the payments are based on Life Expectancy, they can be stopped but not changed (although it should be possible to stop life expectancy payments and then start another withdrawal option). === Required Minimum Distribution === Required Minimum Distributions are required from the TSP under the same rules as for other employer plans:{{cite web| url=https://www.tsp.gov/publications/tspbk26.pdf| title=Tax Rules About TSP Payments}}{{cite web| url=https://www.tsp.gov/news-and-resources/secure-2-0-and-the-tsp/| title=Secure 2.0 and the TSP}} {{Blockquote|The Internal Revenue Code (IRC) requires that you begin receiving distributions from your account in the calendar year you become age 73 and are separated from federal service. Your TSP traditional balance is subject to these required minimum distributions (RMDs). Roth balances do not require RMDs. If you have a civilian or uniformed services TSP account, we calculate RMDs using your age, your prior year-end account balance, and the IRS Uniform Lifetime Table.
Any distributions you make while subject to RMDs will be used to satisfy the requirement. If the total amount of your distributions does not satisfy the requirement, we will issue a supplemental payment for the remaining amount before the deadline each year.}} == Roth TSP == As an employer sponsored retirement plan, the Roth TSP, like a [[Roth 401(k)]], has [[IRA distribution tables|required minimum distributions]].{{Cite web | title = Retirement Plans FAQs regarding Required Minimum Distributions| publisher = IRS | date = 2017-11-16 | accessdate = 2017-11-24 | url = https://www.irs.gov/retirement-plans/retirement-plans-faqs-regarding-required-minimum-distributions | quote = The RMD rules apply to all employer sponsored retirement plans, including profit-sharing plans, 401(k) plans, 403(b) plans, and 457(b) plans. The RMD rules also apply to traditional IRAs and IRA-based plans such as SEPs, SARSEPs, and SIMPLE IRAs. The RMD rules also apply to Roth 401(k) accounts. However, the RMD rules do not apply to Roth IRAs while the owner is alive.}} According to the TSP, "Required minimum distributions apply to both traditional and Roth balances and are paid proportionally from both balances."{{Cite web | title = TSP: Special Withdrawal Considerations | publisher = TSP | accessdate = 2017-11-24 | url = https://www.tsp.gov/PlanParticipation/LoansAndWithdrawals/withdrawals/specialConsiderations.html#rmd}} One of the many advantages of [[Roth IRA]]s is that they are not subject to RMD. Employer sponsored retirement plans like the Roth TSP and Roth 401(k)s, by contrast, do not enjoy that advantage unless they are rolled over to a Roth IRA. For TSP participants who expect to have significant Roth TSP balances, who would prefer not to withdraw from those balances, and who want to remain in the TSP, the decision to contribute to the Roth TSP should be reconsidered, since they will be required to take RMDs on any Roth balance. Alternatively, a full withdrawal of both Traditional and Roth contributions is possible. Or you could withdraw everything except for the minimum $200,{{cite web| url=https://www.tsp.gov/planparticipation/withdrawals/accountOptions.shtml| title=Options after Leaving Federal Service| publisher=TSP.gov}} putting the Roth TSP amount into a Roth IRA and the Traditional TSP amount into a Traditional IRA, and then transferring the Traditional IRA amount back into the TSP.{{Cite web | title = How To Get Your Tax-Exempt TSP Money In To A Roth IRA | author = The White Coat Investor| author-link=The White Coat Investor | date = 2013-08-19 | accessdate = 2017-11-24 | url = https://www.whitecoatinvestor.com/how-to-get-your-tax-exempt-tsp-money-in-to-a-roth-ira/}} A qualified Roth 401(k) distribution is generally a distribution that is made after a 5-taxable-year period of participation and is either: *made on or after the date you attain age 59½ *made after your death, or *attributable to your being disabled. When you roll over a distribution from a designated Roth account to a Roth IRA, the period that the rolled-over funds were in the designated Roth account '''does not count''' toward the 5-taxable-year period for determining qualified distributions from the Roth IRA. However, if you had contributed to any Roth IRA in a prior year, the 5-taxable-year period for determining qualified distributions from a Roth IRA is measured from the earlier contribution. So, if the earlier contribution was made more than 5 years ago and you are over 59½ a distribution of amounts attributable to a rollover contribution from a designated Roth account would be a qualified distribution from the Roth IRA. If you take a distribution from your designated Roth account before the end of the 5-taxable-year period, it is a nonqualified distribution. You must include the earnings portion of the nonqualified distribution in gross income. However, the basis (or contributions) portion of the nonqualified distribution is not included in gross income. The basis portion of the distribution is determined by multiplying the amount of the nonqualified distribution by the ratio of designated Roth contributions to the total designated Roth account balance. For example, if a nonqualified distribution of $5,000 is made from your designated Roth account when the account consists of $9,400 of designated Roth contributions and $600 of earnings, the distribution consists of $4,700 of designated Roth contributions (that are not includible in your gross income) and $300 of earnings (that are includible in your gross income). See [http://www.irs.gov/Retirement-Plans/Retirement-Plans-FAQs-on-Designated-Roth-Accounts#distns FAQ's on Designated Roth Accounts], from the IRS. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{TSP}} [[Category:Thrift Savings Plan]]

{{US}}
[[Thrift Savings Plan]] participants should be aware of IRS rules for eligible employer retirement plans and TSP-specific beneficiary rules in order to optimize their estate planning.
== Beneficiaries == [[File:TSPEstatePlanningBP.jpg|thumb|Figure 1. TSP Estate Planning inheritance succession when surviving spouse remains in the TSP as a beneficiary participant. By remaining in the TSP as a beneficiary participant, when the surviving spouse dies, their benefit is paid as taxable income.]] Much like other retirement accounts, TSP account holders may designate beneficiaries for their account.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.tsp.gov/planparticipation/beneficiaries/beneficiaries.shtml| title=TSP Beneficiaries| publisher=TSP}}</ref>
When a TSP participant dies, a surviving spouse beneficiary can assume the TSP account as a TSP [[TSP_estate_planning#Beneficiary_participants|beneficiary participant]].<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.tsp.gov/planparticipation/beneficiaryparticipants/yourAccount.shtml| title=Your Beneficiary Participant Account| publisher=TSP}}</ref>
Non-spouse beneficiaries cannot maintain the TSP account. The death benefit payment will be made directly to the beneficiary or to an [[Inheriting an IRA|inherited IRA]].<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.tsp.gov/PDF/formspubs/tspbk31.pdf| title=Death Benefits: Information for Participants and Beneficiaries| publisher=TSP}} (Located at [https://www.tsp.gov/planparticipation/beneficiaries/beneficiaries.shtml TSP Beneficiaries].)</ref>
Important terms for account holders and beneficiaries are summarized below: {|border=1 cellpadding=7 |- style="background:#f0f0f0;" ! Term ! Notes |- | TSP Participant | The actual TSP account holder who is a Federal or armed services employee. |- | Direct beneficiary | Any beneficiaries of a TSP account when the TSP participant dies. These may be primary or contingent beneficiaries. |- | Beneficiary participant | If one of the direct beneficiaries was the TSP participant's spouse, then the spouse may choose to retain the TSP account. Upon doing so, the surviving spouse becomes a TSP holder, but as a beneficiary participant and not as an ordinary TSP participant. Per TSP rules, only a surviving spouse can become a beneficiary participant. As described elsewhere, beneficiary participants do not have as many abilities as ordinary TSP participants. |- | Successor beneficiary | A beneficiary participant can designate beneficiaries for when the beneficiary participant dies. Anyone who inherits a TSP account from a beneficiary participant is a successor beneficiary. |}
Following are several examples of estate planning scenarios using the terms above: * Fran is a Federal employee and a '''TSP participant''' * Harry is Fran's husband. He is not a Federal employee. * Debra is Harry and Fran's daughter.
Fran dies. Fran's beneficiary designations leave 70% of her TSP balance to Harry and 30% to Debra. Harry and Debra are both '''direct beneficiaries'''. Debra cannot hold a TSP account since she is a not the account holder's spouse, and chooses instead to rollover her death benefit into an inherited IRA. Harry, as the spouse of TSP participant, has several options as illustrated below.
=== Scenario 1 - Beneficiary participant stays in TSP === Figure 1 illustrates this scenario.
Harry keeps the TSP as a '''beneficiary participant''', and designates Debra as his primary beneficiary of his beneficiary TSP account.
Harry dies and Debra, as Harry's primary beneficiary, becomes a '''successor beneficiary'''. The TSP issues a taxable distribution to Debra.
If Harry's goal was to maximize the value of his daughter's inheritance, then this strategy is flawed because Debra must report her benefit as a taxable distribution.
=== Scenario 2 - Beneficiary participant rolls over TSP into inherited IRA === [[File:TSPEstatePlanningIIRA.jpg|thumb|Figure 2. TSP Estate Planning inheritance succession when surviving spouse rolls over TSP beneficiary participant account to inherited IRA. This scenario contrasts with the scenario in Figure 1, in which the surviving spouse rolls stays in the TSP as a beneficiary participant.]]
Instead of staying in the TSP as a beneficiary participant after Fran dies, Harry instead chooses to roll over the TSP funds into his IRA. Since Harry was Fran's spouse, he can transfer Fran's TSP into his own IRA instead of being required to set up an inherited IRA. At this point, the original TSP account is permanently closed.
Harry sets Debra as the beneficiary of his IRA. Upon Harry's death, Debra can establish an inherited IRA from her father's IRA, thereby preserving the tax-advantaged state of the funds.
If Harry's goal was to maximize Debra's inheritance, then this is the ideal strategy. See Figure 2 for an illustration of this scenario.
=== Scenario 3 - Beneficiary participant stays in TSP and bequeaths to charity ===
Similar to Scenario #1, Harry stays in the TSP as a '''beneficiary participant''' and chooses a charitable organization as his TSP beneficiary. Upon his death, the charitable organization will inherit his TSP as a distribution. Since this kind of distribution is generally tax-free to the receiving charitable organization, this is a good strategy if the goal is to benefit a charity.
If, however, Harry is leaving other taxable assets to heirs, then Harry could arguably arrange his estate in a better way to maximize the post-tax value to his heirs; for example, leave taxable assets to the charity (who likely will not need to pay the taxes) and leave tax-advantaged assets like an IRA (created from the TSP he inherited from Fran) to individual heirs who would have paid taxes on taxable assets.
== Beneficiary participants ==
A '''beneficiary participant''' is a spouse who inherited a TSP participant's account.
Although in most respects a beneficiary participant is just like an ordinary TSP participant, a beneficiary participant has certain important restrictions compared to ordinary TSP participants.
=== Rollovers and transfers === Beneficiary participants cannot do [[TSP transfers and rollovers]] into the TSP.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.tsp.gov/PDF/formspubs/tspbk33.pdf| title=Your TSP Account: A Guide for Beneficiary Participants| publisher=TSP}}</ref>
=== Successor beneficiaries of direct beneficiary === {{Quote |title=Successor Beneficiaries of TSP Beneficiary Participants |quote=“<nowiki>[T]</nowiki>here is a very important tax planning issue to keep in mind about a beneficiary participant account. When the beneficiary spouse dies, his/her <nowiki>[successor]</nowiki> beneficiaries may not transfer or roll over the money to an IRA. The money left in the account must be paid to the successor beneficiary(ies) as a single payment and may not be transferred or rolled over to an IRA. This could create a tax burden on the beneficiaries of the spousal account. (This is not a TSP rule, but an outcome required by the Internal Revenue Code.)” |source=Kim Weaver, director of external affairs for the Federal Retirement Thrift Investment Board, Sept. 25, 2014.<ref name="fede_Whyi">{{Cite web | title = Why it's important to check your TSP account before you really check out! | author = Mike Causey | publisher = FederalNewsRadio.com | date = September 25, 2014 | accessdate = March 2, 2017 | url = https://federalnewsradio.com/federal-report/2014/09/why-its-important-to-check-your-tsp-account-before-you-really-check-out/}}</ref>}} As an eligible retirement plan, the TSP (like 401(k), 403(b) and 457 plans) must observe IRS rules regarding successor beneficiaries of direct beneficiaries. As described in [[401(k)#Successor_beneficiaries|401(k) successor beneficiaries]], successor beneficiaries may not rollover an inherited account to an inherited IRA.
According to the TSP:<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.tsp.gov/PDF/formspubs/tspbk31.pdf| title=Death Benefits: Information for Participants and Beneficiaries| p=11| publisher=TSP}} (Located at [https://www.tsp.gov/planparticipation/beneficiaries/beneficiaries.shtml TSP Beneficiaries].)</ref> {{blockquote|If a beneficiary participant dies, the new beneficiary(ies) <nowiki>[</nowiki>successor beneficiaries<nowiki>]</nowiki> cannot continue to maintain the account in the TSP. Also, the death benefit payment cannot be transferred or rolled over into any type of IRA or plan.}}
The inability of a successor beneficiary of a TSP to create an [[Inheriting an IRA|inherited IRA]] with their death benefit portion of a TSP is a significant consideration with estate planning, as it could leave the successor beneficiary with a large taxable distribution. Therefore, spousal survivors who inherit their deceased spouse's TSP may wish to consider rolling the TSP into an IRA if they wish to preserve the tax-advantaged status of these assets for their own beneficiaries; see Figure 2 on this page illustrating this scenario.<ref>{{Forum link|t=147599|title=TSP Beneficiary Account and Tax Burden to Successors|date=25 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{Forum link|t=148054|title= TSP - CNN Money: Fed Workers... low cost retirement plans|date=2 October 2014}}</ref>
