{{US|reason=irrelevant}} {{401k rollover infobox}} You can '''rollover and transfer''' amounts from the following plans into an '''IRA''':{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590a| title=Publication 590-A, Contributions to Individual Retirement Arrangements (IRAs)| publisher=IRS| accessdate=August 21, 2025}} *A [[traditional IRA|traditional IRA]], *An employer's [[401(k)|qualified retirement plan]] for its employees, *A deferred compensation plan of a state or local government ([[457(b)|section 457 plan]]) *A tax-sheltered annuity plan ([[403(b)|section 403 plan]]) ==Types of transfers== ===Direct trustee-to-trustee transfers=== You can transfer funds in one traditional IRA from one trustee directly to another, either at your request or at the trustee's request, through a direct trustee-to-trustee transfer. Because there is no distribution of assets to the plan holder, the transfer does not trigger the 10% early withdrawal penalty tax, and is tax free (an amount rolled over tax free from one retirement plan to another is generally includible in income when it is distributed from the second plan). There is no withholding tax imposed on the transfer. You can make an unlimited number of trustee-to-trustee transfers in a given year. If you want to transfer a qualified plan, your employer's qualified plan must give you the option to have any part of an eligible rollover distribution paid directly to a traditional IRA. The plan is not required to give you this option if your eligible rollover distributions are expected to total less than $200 for the year. When executing trustee-to-trustee transfers you need to carefully monitor the transfer process to make sure that the transaction goes ahead without error. ===Rollovers=== Generally, a rollover is a tax-free distribution to you of cash or other assets from one retirement plan that you contribute to another retirement plan. The contribution to the second retirement plan is called a "rollover contribution". Unlike the direct trustee-to-trustee transfer process which bypasses the individual plan holder, a rollover is executed by distributing a paid out check to the plan holder who must then transfer the proceeds to a new retirement plan account. Rollovers have the following characteristics: *You must make the rollover contribution by the 60th day after the day you receive the distribution from your traditional IRA or your employer's plan. The IRS may waive the 60-day requirement where the failure to do so would be unreasonable; for example, you suffered a casualty, disaster, or other event beyond your control. Failing to meet the 60 day requirement results in the distribution becoming taxable, and may also trigger any 10% early withdrawal tax. *If an eligible rollover distribution is paid directly to you the payer must usually withhold 20% of it. This applies even if you plan to roll over the distribution to a traditional IRA. Exceptions to the withholding requirement include a distribution totaling less than $200; or a distribution consisting solely of employer securities, plus cash of $200 or less in lieu of fractional shares. If you do not want to pay income tax or penalty tax on the 20% withheld for tax, you must use outside funds to make the rollover the full 100%. This would be considered an indirect rollover. *Conversely, if a distribution is made payable directly to the trustee of the rollover destination account (and actually rolled over), it can be treated as a direct rollover and not be subject to withholding. *You are limited to only one rollover per one-year period per individual, regardless of how many IRAs you own or their type (traditional, SEP, SIMPLE, Roth). The one-year period begins on the date you receive the IRA distribution, not on the date you roll it over into an IRA. (The once-a-year limit on IRA-to-IRA rollovers does not apply to eligible rollover distributions from an employer plan. You can roll over more than one distribution from the same employer plan within a year.) Here is an IRS summary of allowable rollover transactions: {| style="border-collapse: collapse;" border="1" |+'''Rollover chart'''{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/rollover_chart.pdf| title=Rollover chart| publisher=IRS| accessdate=August 21, 2025}} |- ||[[File:IRS Rollover Chart.png|800px]]
:1Qualified plans include, for example, profit-sharing, 401(k), money purchase and defined benefit plans.
:2Only one rollover in any 12-month period.
:3Must include in income.
:4Must have separate accounts.
:5Must be an in-plan rollover.
:6Any nontaxable amounts distributed must be rolled over via direct trustee-to-trustee transfer.
:7Applies to rollover contributions after December 18, 2015. |} ===Transfers incident to a divorce=== If you receive interest in a traditional IRA from your spouse or former spouse to you by a divorce (or separate maintenance decree or a written document related to such a decree), the interest in the IRA, starting from the date of the transfer, is treated as your IRA. The transfer is tax free. There are two commonly-used ways to transfer IRA assets to a spouse or former spouse. These are: *'''Changing the name on the IRA.''' If all the assets are to be transferred, you can make the transfer by changing the name on the IRA from your name to the name of your spouse or former spouse. *'''Making a direct transfer of IRA assets.''' Here you direct the trustee of the traditional IRA to transfer the affected assets directly to the trustee of a new or existing traditional IRA set up in the name of your spouse or former spouse. If your spouse or former spouse is allowed to keep their portion of the IRA assets in your existing IRA, you can direct the trustee to transfer the assets you are permitted to keep directly to a new or existing traditional IRA, set up in your name. The name on the IRA containing your spouse's or former spouse's portion of the assets would then be changed to show their ownership. ===Rollovers/transfers to a Health Savings Account (HSA)=== You can make a once in a lifetime rollover or transfer from an IRA to an[[Health savings account| HSA]] up to the annual HSA funding limit. This is usually not a good idea, because you would lose the ability to contribute and take an HSA tax deduction for the amount you transfer, but it can be an emergency source of funds without paying taxes or penalties. See [https://www.irs.gov/irb/2008-51_IRB IRS Notice 2008-51]. This also may not be a good idea if you live in a state that taxes HSAs. See [[Health savings account#Rollovers/Transfers|HSA rollovers/transfers]] for more details. ==Rollover (conduit) IRA== A lot of traditional IRAs are the result of employee rollovers from employer plans to individually held IRAs. People rollover plan assets when they change jobs, and often, when they retire. This lets them consolidate retirement assets into a single account, reduce costs, and expand investment options. These accounts are often termed Rollover or Conduit IRAs. Before the [[wikipedia:Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001|Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001]], the only way for an employee to transfer assets from one employer plan to another was to establish an uncommingled Conduit IRA. After the passage of the act, you can roll over part or all of the Conduit IRA to a qualified plan, even if you make regular contributions to it or add funds from sources other than your employer's plan. However, if your retirement account includes qualified-plan balances that accrued before 1974, or if you were born before 1936, you may qualify for special optional tax treatment of lump sum distributions. These options include capital gains and forward averaging tax treatments. You must not commingle contributions or add funds from other sources to the Conduit IRA if you want to preserve these options.{{cite web| author=Denise Appleby| url=http://www.investopedia.com/articles/retirement/03/051403.asp| title=Combining Your Plan Assets? Not So Fast!| publisher=Investopedia| date=September 8, 2014| url-status=dead| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190117214314/http://www.investopedia.com/articles/retirement/03/051403.asp| archive-date=January 17, 2019}} You can also rollover employer plan assets into a [[Roth IRA]]. This is considered a conversion, and you will be liable for income tax the amount transferred. If you are transferring assets from an employer plan including both regular 401(K) and Roth 401(k) assets, you can rollover to both a [[Traditional IRA]] and a [[Roth IRA]]. If you are rolling over assets from an IRA into an employer provided plan, keep in mind that a qualified plan can accept only pre-tax contributions; any portion of an IRA which has a tax basis cannot be rolled over. You can roll this tax basis portion of the IRA, tax-free, into a Roth IRA. If you own company stock in a retirement plan you may be able to take advantage of a special set of rules that allow you to pay only capital gains taxes on a significant portion of the distribution. See [[Net unrealized appreciation]] for fuller details. Assets held in ERISA plans usually have greater protection from creditors than assets held in an IRA. See [[Asset_protection#Investing_in_an_IRA | Asset protection:Investing in an IRA]] for considerations of asset protection when rolling over assets from an ERISA plan into an IRA. == Roth IRA == While you can roll over a Roth 401(k) (as well as other equivalent eligible employer plans) into a Roth IRA, it is not possible to do the opposite. From IRS publication 590-A: {{blockquote|A rollover from a Roth IRA to an employer retirement plan isn’t allowed.}} Additionally, from IRS retirement plan FAQs:{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/retirement-plans/retirement-plans-faqs-regarding-iras| title=Retirement plans FAQs regarding IRAs| publisher=IRS| accessdate=August 21, 2025}} {{blockquote|You can roll over your IRA into a qualified retirement plan (for example, a 401(k) plan), assuming the retirement plan has language allowing it to accept this type of rollover. Roth IRAs can only be rolled over to another Roth IRA.}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/rollover_chart.pdf Rollover chart] - IRS *[https://www.irs.gov/retirement-plans/plan-participant-employee/rollovers-of-retirement-plan-and-ira-distributions Rollovers of Retirement Plan and IRA Distributions] - IRS *[http://www.irs.gov/publications/p590a/ Publication 590-A, Contributions to Individual Retirement Arrangements (IRAs)] *[http://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b/ Publication 590-B, Distributions from Individual Retirement Arrangements (IRAs)] *[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p590.pdf IRS Publication 590 Individual Retirement Arrangements (IRAs)] - IRS. Superseded by publications 590-A and 590-B after 2013. *[https://www.investopedia.com/articles/retirement/06/rollovermistakes.asp Common IRA Rollover Mistakes], from Investopedia {{Retirement accounts|state=collapsed}} {{Managing your IRA|state=collapsed}} [[Category:IRAs]]

{{US|reason=irrelevant}} If you are holding your employer's [[stock basics|stock]] in your employer provided [[Qualified retirement plan|qualified plan]], '''{{PAGENAME}}''' uses a special favorable section of the tax law that allows you to to pay capital gains tax rates on the stock if you are separating from service with your employer, the plan is distributed in a lump sum, and the stock was purchased by your contributions and employer matches. ==Net unrealised appreciation== The Net unrealised appreciation (NUA) of the stock is not taxed when distributed, and is taxed at capital gains tax rates when sold. Only the taxable cost basis of the stock is recognized as a taxable distribution. {| class="wikitable" width="100%" | Example
Chris is set to retire from his job with Coca-Cola,Inc. His 401(k) contains $1.1 million dollars of Coca-Cola stock. The 401(k) administrator informs Chris that he has a basis of $300,000 in the stock and $800,000 of NUA. Instead of rolling the 401(k) over into an IRA, Chris elects to take out the stock under the NUA tax rules. The $300,000 basis is deemed a distribution from the 401(k) and is subject to income tax, and if Chris is less than 55, a 10% early withdrawal penalty tax. The $800,000 NUA is not taxed upon distribution. If Chris sells the stock upon distribution, it will be taxed as a long term capital gain. If Chris holds on to the stock, he can defer tax until he sells. Any further realized short term gain on the stock will be taxed as a short term capital gain; any further realized gain held for more than a year is taxed as a long term gain.{{cite book| author=Natalie Choate| title=Life and Death Planning for Retirement Benefits| edition=6th| date=2006| isbn=978-0-9649440-7-7| pp=138-139| ref={{SfnRef|Choate|2006}}}} |} Note that it is the employer or the plan that determines the basis and NUA. Beneficiaries of a retirement plan can also take advantage of the NUA rules. The IRS considers this to be [[Income in respect of a decedent|income in respect of a decedent]] (IRD). The NUA is taxed at capital gains tax rates when sold, and the beneficiaries get to take a deduction on any estate tax attributable to the NUA. If the NUA is distributed and held until death, the beneficiaries do not receive step up valuation of the NUA (it still retains its character as NUA and becomes [[Income in respect of a decedent| income in respect of a decedent]] taxed as a long term capital gain). Any appreciation in the stock beyond the NUA does qualify for stepped up valuation. Qualified plan participants often hold a mixture of company stock and other investments. In this instance, the lump sum distribution would rollover the non NUA assets and not rollover the NUA. {| class="wikitable" width="100%" | Example
Mary takes a lump sum distribution from her company 401(k) plan. Her $450,000 plan balance includes $80,000 of her employer's stock. The balance of her assets are in mutual funds. Her plan informs her that she has a basis of $30,000 in the stock. Mary rolls over (in a trustee-to-trustee transfer) the $370,000 of mutual fund investments and takes a distribution of the stock. She will pay income tax (and any applicable early withdrawal penalty taxes) on the $30,000 basis. Her $50,000 NUA will be taxed at capital gains tax rates when sold.{{sfn|Choate|2006|pp=143-144}} |} When taking a distribution of NUA stock, it is advisable to not commingle the NUA stock with employer stock already held in a taxable account. You should set up a separate account for holding the NUA stock.{{cite web| url=https://www.investopedia.com/investing/rolling-over-company-stock/| title=Rolling Over Company Stock from a 401(k): When It Does—and Doesn't—Make Sense| publisher=Investopedia| date=January 16, 2023| accessdate=May 14, 2024}} The decision as to whether to rollover employer stock or take the NUA distribution is a quantifiable decision. In general, a young employee changing jobs and having a small NUA would likely decide to roll the stock over to a rollover [[IRA rollovers and transfers|IRA]], whereas a 70 year old retiree facing imminent [[Required Minimum Distribution vs annuitization|Required Minimum Distribution]] would likely take the NUA distribution. Obviously, if the amount of NUA in a plan is large, taking the NUA distribution would be appealing. The following advanced considerations concerning NUA require the aid of a professional retirement plan specialist: * Rolling over the employer's basis in the plan and taking distribution of only the NUA. * Contributing the NUA distribution to a Charitable Remainder Trust (private letter IRS authorization will be necessary.{{sfn|Choate|2006|pp=138-145}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.kitces.com/blog/net-unrealized-appreciation-irs-rules-nua-from-401k-and-esop-plans/ Why The Net Unrealized Appreciation (NUA) Rules Aren’t Always A Great Deal], Michael Kitces, July 12 2017, viewed May 14, 2024. *[https://www.fidelity.com/learning-center/personal-finance/retirement/company-stock Make the most of company stock], Fidelity Investments, November 14, 2023, viewed May 14, 2024. *[https://www.investopedia.com/investing/rolling-over-company-stock/ Rolling Over Company Stock from a 401(k): When It Does—and Doesn't—Make Sense], from Investopedia *[https://www.ataxplan.com/ Ataxplan Publications], Natalie Choate's web site {{Managing your IRA}} [[Category:IRAs]] [[Category:Tax considerations]]

{{US}}
If you '''inherit an IRA''' (Individual Retirement Arrangement), you are called a beneficiary. A beneficiary can be any person or entity the owner chooses to receive the benefits of the IRA after they die. Beneficiaries of a traditional IRA must include in their gross income any taxable distributions they receive.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=Internal Revenue Service|title=Topic no. 451, Individual retirement arrangements (IRAs)|url=https://www.irs.gov/taxtopics/tc451}}</ref><ref name=":0" />
IRAs can be held at a bank or other financial institution or with a mutual fund or life insurance company.<ref name=":0">{{cite web |url=https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590a| title=Publication 590-A (2023), Contributions to Individual Retirement Arrangements (IRAs)| publisher=Internal Revenue Service| accessdate=April 25, 2024}}</ref>
In almost all cases, it is advantageous to name the primary and contingent beneficiaries you wish to inherit your IRA, as opposed to not naming beneficiaries and having the IRA go through will/estate/probate.
You can also choose not to inherit the IRA; known as "disclaiming" the assets. This may be useful if you want the benefits to go to someone else, or do not want to pay taxes on the assets.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.investopedia.com/articles/retirement/03/041603.asp| title=Disclaiming Inherited Plan Assets| publisher=Investopedia| date=June 14, 2022| accessdate=April 25, 2024}}</ref>{{#tag:ref|If you decide to disclaim in full or partial, taking the year of death RMD does not constitute acceptance of the IRA, so you can still take the year of death RMD and then disclaim. This is LIMITED to the year of death RMD, and there are still other formal requirements for a qualified disclaimer. You do not all have to disclaim, or disclaim the same amount, but future equitable accounting may become complicated if any of you diverge.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://easysite.commonwealth.com/EasySites/EasySite_T9193Y/_uploads/How%20and%20Why%20to%20Disclaim%20an%20IRA.pdf| title=How and Why to Disclaim an IRA.pdf| url-status=dead| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306045952/http://easysite.commonwealth.com/EasySites/EasySite_T9193Y/_uploads/How%20and%20Why%20to%20Disclaim%20an%20IRA.pdf| archive-date=March 6, 2016}}</ref> However, doing it this way can be complicated. It is simpler to do the disclaimer first, and then for the beneficiaries (determined after the disclaimer) to set up separate inherited IRAs and take the distributions pro rata.<ref>{{forum link| p=2064911| title=Inherited IRA decision}}</ref>|group="note"}}
==Types of IRA beneficiaries==
The Secure Act modified the RMD rules for certain beneficiaries of inherited IRAs. IRA beneficiaries post Secure Act can now be classified into three categories:<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.investopedia.com/not-designated-beneficiary-definition-5025735| title=Not Designated Beneficiaries|publisher=Investopedia}}</ref>
1. Eligible Designated Beneficiaries (EDB). There are specific requirements to qualify for EDB status, which entitles the individual beneficiaries to a lifetime stretch, similar to prior to the SECURE act.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.morningstar.com/retirement/ed-slott-how-eligible-designated-beneficiaries-changed|title=How Rules on Eligible Designated Beneficiaries Changed for Inherited IRAs| author1=Christine Benz| author2=Ed Slott |publisher=Morningstar|date=May 9, 2024}}</ref> The beneficiaries must be individuals or “see through” trusts in which the trust’s individual beneficiary qualifies as an EDB.
The following are considered eligible designated beneficiaries and still qualify for a lifetime stretch:
*The owner’s surviving spouse *The owner’s child who is less than 21 years of age<ref>{{cite web| url=https://irahelp.com/slottreport/age-majority-and-new-secure-act-regulations/#:~:text=The%20age%20of%20majority%20is,required%20minimum%20distribution%20(RMD).| title=AGE OF MAJORITY AND THE NEW SECURE ACT REGULATION| author1=Andy Ives| author2=Ed Slott | publisher=The Slott Report|date=March 2, 2022}}</ref><ref group="note">The child is allowed to stretch IRA payments until they are 21. At that time, the 10-year payout rule will apply, and the now-adult child will have another 10 years to maintain the inherited IRA. </ref> *A disabled individual *A chronically ill individual<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.wealthmanagement.com/estate-planning/special-needs-trusts-can-help-secure-stretch-ira| title=Special Needs Trusts Can Help SECURE a 'Stretch' IRA| author1=Robert Dietz | author2=Jennifer Goode | publisher=Wealth Management|date=April 20, 2023}}</ref> *Any other individual who is not more than 10 years younger than the deceased IRA owner<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.kitces.com/blog/secure-act-stretch-ira-401k-elimination-eligible-designated-beneficiary-retirement-accounts-taxes/| title=The (Partial) Death Of The Stretch IRA: How The SECURE Act Impacts Inherited Retirement Accounts| author=Michael Kitces| date=February 12, 2020}}</ref>
2. Non-Eligible Designated Beneficiaries - this category now must liquidate IRA holdings within a 10 year period (the 10 year rule). Many designated beneficiaries were formerly eligible for a lifetime stretch. These beneficiaries are typically all other individuals who are not EDBs (including “see through” trusts where the individual beneficiary if the trust falls into this category).
3. Not/Non Designated Beneficiaries - These include beneficiaries that are entities and not persons, such as an estate, a non see through trust and charities. These are subject to different rules, one of which could include distribution from the IRA over a 5 year period.{{#tag:ref| If the estate remains the IRA beneficiary, the IRA must be distributed according to the following rules: *If the IRA owner has started taking required minimum distributions, the IRA must be distributed at least as quickly as the decedent's remaining required minimum distributions. * If the IRA owner is not taking required minimum distributions the IRA must be distributed according to the five-year rule. Under the five-year rule, the assets must be distributed by December 31 of the fifth year since the retirement account owner's death.{{sfn|Choate|2006|pp=89-90}}<ref>{{cite web| url= https://www.schwab.com/learn/story/inheriting-ira-understand-your-options | title= Inheriting an IRA? Understand Your Choices | author=Hayden Adams| publisher=Schwab|date=May 1, 2024}}</ref> |group="note"}} A [[Charitable remainder trust]] is an exception to this and can be an advantageous way to leave traditional IRA assets mostly to an individual with a remainder to charity.
==IRA inherited from your spouse== {{Quote |quote = '''<u>Spousal Inheritance of an IRA'''</u> You will only be considered to have chosen to treat the IRA as your own if: * You are the sole beneficiary of the IRA, and * You have an unlimited right to withdraw amounts from it.<ref>{{cite book| author=Natalie Choate| title=Life and Death Planning for Retirement Benefits| edition=6th| date=2006| isbn=978-0-9649440-7-7| p=169| ref={{SfnRef|Choate|2006}}}}</ref>
You will be considered to have chosen to treat the IRA as your own if: * Contributions (including rollover contributions) are made to the inherited IRA, or * You do not take the required minimum distribution for a year as a beneficiary of the IRA.{{sfn|Choate|2006|p=170}}}} If you inherit a traditional IRA from your spouse, you generally have the following three choices. You can: :1. Treat it as your own IRA by designating yourself as the account owner. :2. Treat it as your own by rolling it over into your traditional IRA, or to the extent it is taxable, into a: :* Qualified employer plan, :* Qualified employee annuity plan (section 403(a) plan), :* Tax-sheltered annuity plan (section 403(b) plan), :* Deferred compensation plan of a state or local government (section 457 plan), or :3. Treat yourself as the beneficiary rather than treating the IRA as your own.<ref name="590B">{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b| title=Publication 590-B (2023), Distributions from Individual Retirement Arrangements (IRAs)| publisher=IRS| accessdate=April 25, 2024}} (What if You Inherit an IRA?)</ref>
There are a number of clear advantages to spousal rollovers of an IRA. *By using a spousal rollover, the surviving spouse can use their own age and Uniform Lifetime Table based life expectancy for starting Required Minimum Distributions from the IRA. Often this can mean a longer period for tax deferral of the IRA.{{#tag:ref|In the first year of ownership, you must take the deceased owner's [[Required Minimum Distribution vs annuitization | RMD]] for that year (to the extent it was not already distributed to the owner before their death).<ref name="590B" />|group="note"}} *With a spousal rollover, the surviving spouse can use the IRS Uniform Lifetime Table, which is based upon the combined life expectancy of the owner and someone ten years younger, rather than the typically less favorable Single Life table. The uniform tables provide for a slower payout of required minimum distributions. *A spousal rollover allows a surviving spouse to name primary and contingent beneficiaries to the IRA. This allows the surviving spouse, if the situation warrants, to correct any problems in the original beneficiary designations. These beneficiaries will follow current IRS rules, typically requiring full distribution within 10 years unless they qualify as Eligible Designated Beneficiaries. * If the spouse opts to inherit the IRA rather than executing a rollover, the distribution of the IRA will be distributed over the Single Life Table life expectancy of the spouse if the owner died before the RBD (currently 73). If the owner died after the RBD, the spouse uses the longer of their own Single Life Table or the deceased owner's remaining life expectancy." * As of 2024, final regulations were issued surrounding the Secure Act 2.0, and an additional option was created for spouses. Spouses can choose to inherit the IRA, but instead use the more favorable uniform lifetime RMD table, instead of the less favorable single lifetime table.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.kitces.com/blog/rmd-spousal-election-secure-2-0-secure-act-rmd-rules-spousal-beneficiaries-retirement-account/| title=New RMD Rules For Spousal Beneficiaries Of Retirement Accounts With SECURE 2.0’s “Spousal Election” Option| publisher=Kitces.com| accessdate=October 24, 2025}}</ref>
A spouse might decide to forgo a spousal rollover if they are under the age of 59 1/2 and have a clear need for the income from the IRA. Before the 2024 final regulations, as beneficiary, the surviving spouse was required to take minimum distributions based on the Single Life Table from the account. Withdrawals would be exempt from the 10% early withdrawal penalty tax.{{sfn|Choate|2006|pp=164-165}} After the 2024 updated regulations, the spousal beneficiary can choose use to use the more favorable uniform lifetime table.
If you do not explicitly act to make an election (that is, you do not retitle the account and do not take an RMD as required), it defaults to "treat IRA as your own."
==IRA inherited from someone other than your spouse== If you inherit a traditional IRA from anyone other than your deceased spouse, you cannot treat the inherited IRA as your own. This means that you cannot make any contributions to the IRA. It also means you cannot roll over any amounts into or out of the inherited IRA. However, you can make a trustee-to-trustee transfer as long as the IRA into which amounts are being moved is set up and maintained in the name of the deceased IRA owner for the benefit of you as beneficiary.<ref name="590B" />
Like the original owner, you generally will not owe tax on the assets in the IRA until you receive distributions from it. With the passage of the SECURE Act, IRA distributions to a non-spouse must be completed within 10 years following the death of the account owner, unless the beneficiary qualifies as an “eligible designated beneficiary” in which case the beneficiary still qualifies for a lifetime stretch. As of July 2024, the IRS issued final regulations that confirm RMDS are required for years 1-9 for those IRAs subject to the 10 year rule. However this will be enforced starting in 2025, and RMDS not taken from 2021-2024 will be forgiven (including penalties).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://public-inspection.federalregister.gov/2024-14542.pdf| title=Required Minimum Distributions| publisher=Internal Revenue Service|date=July 17, 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.wsj.com/personal-finance/retirement/ira-inheritance-rules-minimum-withdrawals-671b7952?mod=hp_lead_pos11| title=Heirs Finally Get an Answer From IRS About Money in Inherited Retirement Accounts| author= Ashlea Ebeling| publisher=Wall Street Journal|date=July 18, 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url= https://www.morningstar.com/financial-advisors/irs-finalizes-rmd-regulations-key-takeaways-10-year-rule-beneficiaries | title= IRS Finalizes RMD Regulations: Key Takeaways and the 10-Year Rule for Beneficiaries | author=Denise Applebee| publisher=Morningstar|date=July 22, 2024}}</ref><ref name="Levine">{{cite web| url= https://www.kitces.com/blog/secure-act-2-0-irs-regulations-rmd-required-minimum-distributions-10-year-rule-eligible-designated-beneficiary-see-through-conduit-trust/| title= Untangling The IRS’s New Finalized (And Proposed) Regulations On RMDs: The 10-Year Rule, Trust Beneficiaries, Spousal Beneficiaries, Annuities, And More!| author=Jeff Levine| publisher=Kitces.com|date=July 24, 2024}}</ref>{{#tag:ref| In 2022, the IRS issued proposed regulations saying that, in addition to the 10-year rule, beneficiaries of IRA owners who died after their required beginning date would have to take RMDs in years 1 through 9. Due to confusion and controversy surrounding the proposed regulations, the IRS subsequently waived the penalty for not taking RMDs year 1-9 in tax years 2021-2023<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.morningstar.com/retirement/faqs-about-inherited-iras | title=Be Aware of These New Rules for Inherited IRAs| author=Christine Benz| publisher=Morningstar|date=March 20, 2024}}</ref> and 2024.<ref> {{cite web|url=https://www.morningstar.com/personal-finance/irs-extends-waiver-excise-tax-inherited-iras-not-rmds| title=IRS Extends Waiver of Excise Tax for Inherited IRAs, but Not RMDs| author=Denise Appleby| publisher=Morningstar|date=April 24, 2024}}</ref><ref> {{cite web|url=https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-drop/n-24-35.pdf| title= Notice 2024-35-Certain Required Minimum Distributions for 2024| publisher=Internal Revenue Service|date=April 24, 2024}}</ref> Finally, as of July 2024, the IRS issued final regulations that confirm RMDS are required for years 1-9 for those IRAs subject to the 10 year rule. However this will be enforced starting in 2025, and RMDS not taken from 2021-2024 will be forgiven (including penalties).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://public-inspection.federalregister.gov/2024-14542.pdf| title=Required Minimum Distributions| publisher=Internal Revenue Service|date=July 17, 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url= https://www.morningstar.com/financial-advisors/irs-finalizes-rmd-regulations-key-takeaways-10-year-rule-beneficiaries| title= IRS Finalizes RMD Regulations: Key Takeaways and the 10-Year Rule for Beneficiaries | author=Denise Applebee| publisher=Morningstar|date=July 22, 2024}}</ref><ref name="Levine" />|group="note"}}{{#tag:ref|The Single Life Table is used to calculate RMDs for your beneficiaries, but only if they are an “eligible designated beneficiary.” This table is also used if you die after your “required beginning date” (April 1 after your age 73 year) without naming a living beneficiary. The IRS regulations include a special “reset” provision for calculating RMDs for non-spouse beneficiaries who inherit before January 1, 2022.<ref>{{cite web| title=Inheriting IRAs from someone other than your spouse| url=https://www.fidelity.com/learning-center/personal-finance/retirement/non-spouse-IRA| date=February 25, 2020| publisher=Fidelity Viewpoints| accessdate=December 9, 2020| url-status=dead| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240118201112/https://www.fidelity.com/learning-center/personal-finance/retirement/non-spouse-IRA| archive-date=January 18, 2024}}</ref>|group="note"}}
The proposed year 1-9 RMD regulations do not apply to inherited Roth IRAs, in which case all monies merely have to be distributed by the end of year 10. Executors have until December 31 of the year following the death of the decedent owner to properly title and distribute the IRA to the beneficiaries. Multiple beneficiaries should split the IRA into separate interests so that each beneficiary can: *Select a fiduciary of choice for investing the inherited IRA; *Execute their own individual investment plan and account succession.{{sfn|Choate|2006|pp=91-95}}
If an IRA having multiple beneficiaries is not split into separate accounts, the required minimum distribution is based on the life expectancy factor for the oldest beneficiary.{{sfn|Choate|2006|p=90}}
If you establish multiple inherited IRAs you can make tax-free transfers between the inherited IRAs. Although the RMD must be figured on each individual inherited IRA, the RMD can be taken from any of the IRAs.{{sfn|Choate|2006|p=73}}
If you inherit IRAs from more than one individual, you cannot commingle or aggregate the inherited IRAs. Transfers between IRAs and RMD calculations must be made within each group of inherited IRAs.{{sfn|Choate|2006|p=90}}
An inheritor of an IRA can, and should, name primary and contingent beneficiaries to the inherited IRA. The inherited IRA will always retain the required minimum distribution schedule for the original inheritor.{{sfn|Choate|2006|p=95}}
For IRAs inherited by designated beneficiaries and paid out under the 10-year rule, consider tax management when determining the RMD schedule. It is rarely a good idea to wait until the 10th year to withdraw the entire balance, or take RMDs on your own life expectancy for years 1-9.
==IRA inherited by the estate==
If you do not name beneficiaries to the IRA, the IRA will be inherited by your estate and will be distributed to the beneficiaries established by will or intestacy law. An estate executor can still designate an inherited IRA to the beneficiaries, as long as this is completed by December 31 of the year following the decedent's death. Estate executors can use a [http://www.ataxplan.com/bulletinBoard/pdfs/FiducLetterWebVersion.pdf sample letter] to properly execute the transfer of the inherited IRA to beneficiaries.
If the estate remains the IRA beneficiary, the IRA must be distributed according to the following rules: *If the IRA owner has started taking required minimum distributions, the IRA must be distributed at least as quickly as the decedent's remaining required minimum distributions. * If the IRA owner is not taking required minimum distributions the IRA must be distributed according to the five-year rule. Under the five-year rule, the assets must be distributed by December 31 of the fifth year since the retirement account owner's death.{{sfn|Choate|2006|pp=89-90}} * If the IRA left to the estate is directed to the spouse, the spouse may be able to rollover the inherited IRA to her own IRA, in certain cases.<ref name=":1" />
==IRA inherited by a charity==
Because a [[Traditional IRA]] contains a tax liability to the government, it is an attractive account for making a charitable contribution for people wanting to leave charitable bequests. And because a charity pays no income tax on its received gifts, and the testamentary contribution is an Estate Tax deduction, making a full or partial beneficial gift of an IRA balance is often reasonable, especially if the remaining estate is in a taxable account, receiving step-up valuation at death, or is in tax-free [[Roth IRA|Roth IRA accounts]]. It is often a good idea to keep planned charitable IRA contributions in a separate IRA. Using separate IRAs is the safest route as it ensures that individual beneficiaries can use lifetime required minimum distribution of the inherited IRA. A fractional beneficiary designation that includes both individual and charitable beneficiaries can be split by distribution of the charitable interest by September 30 of the year following the death of the IRA owner, or by the establishment of separate accounts by December 31 of the year following the IRA owner's death and allow individual lifetime distribution, but only if the the deadlines are met.{{sfn|Choate|2006|pp=357-359}}
==Advanced beneficiary options== These beneficiary options require the services of a qualified estate planner.
*Naming a [[Trusts#Inherited IRA trusts|trust as an IRA beneficiary]];{{#tag:ref|Trusts can be named as beneficiaries of IRAs/retirement accounts, but special care is needed to make sure the trust is set up and worded correctly and also that the particular trust beneficiaries meet the applicable criteria, such as being individuals (not entities) and meeting “look through” criteria. Failure to comply with these rules may cause the trust to lose its potential 10 year (non-EDB) or lifetime (EDB) stretch distribution status, and revert to the default 5 year distribution status applicable to most entities (non-individuals). It is advisable to seek out an estate planning attorney who is experienced with setting up trusts that ultimately will hold IRAs and/or other retirement accounts.<ref>{{cite web| url= https://ataxplan.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/Estate_Planning_for_Retirement_Benefits_post_SECURE_and_Prop_Regs.pdf | title= Estate Planning for Retirement Benefits Under SECURE and Proposed Treasury Regulations | p=67-75| author=Natalie Choate| publisher=Ataxplan|date=September 8, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url= https://www.ntsa-net.org/industry-intel/marketbeat/naming-your-trust-beneficiary-ira| title= Naming Your Trust as Beneficiary of an IRA| author=NTSA| publisher=National Tax Deferred Association}}</ref>|group="note"}}{{#tag:ref|Leaving an IRA to someone else’s revocable living trust can sometimes be problematic and may reduce the applicable stretch. If the beneficiary is ultimately the spouse, the inherited IRA may be able to be rolled over to a spouse’s own IRA in certain circumstances.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://irahelp.com/irs-allows-spouses-roll-inherited-iras-through-own-trusts-their-iras/| title=IRS Allows Spouses to Roll Inherited IRAs Through Own Trusts to Their IRAs| publisher=Ed Slott and Company, LLC| date=September 8, 2014| accessdate=October 24, 2025}}</ref>|group="note"}} *Disclaiming an IRA; *Naming a [[Charitable remainder trust]], [[Donor advised fund]], or [[Charitable gift annuity]], as an IRA beneficiary.
==Deadlines==
Here are key dates you should keep in mind to make sure you meet the IRS deadlines that apply to the options you choose.
* December 31 of the original account owner's year of death. Prior to revised final IRS regulations on July 19, 2024, if the account owner died on or after their required beginning date (RBD), the RMD for the year must be satisfied if it was not taken in full during the account owner's lifetime. The July 2024 regulations extended the deadline to the later of the beneficiary’s year-of-death tax return deadline—generally April 15, including extensions—or December 31 of the year following the year of death. For most beneficiaries it will likely be the latter.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Rahn|first=Mike|date=December 19, 2024|title=RMD Regulations’ Year-of-Death Rules Yield Both Answers and Questions|url=https://thelink.ascensus.com/articles/2024/12/18/rmd-regulations-year-of-death-rules-yield-both-answers-and-questions|website=Ascensus}}</ref> * December 31 of the year following the original account owner's year of death. If you are taking RMD based on the life-expectancy method, distributions must begin by this date. If you are one of multiple beneficiaries, all beneficiaries must have established separate inherited IRA accounts by this date in order to calculate distributions based upon each beneficiary's own life expectancy. * September 30 of the year following the original account owner's year of death. Important for determining the beneficiary whose life expectancy may be used to calculate RMD (the designated beneficiary). If you are one of multiple beneficiaries of varying ages, all beneficiaries must use the life expectancy factor of the oldest beneficiary who has not taken a lump-sum distribution or disclaimed their entire interest prior to this date. However, if all of the beneficiaries have established separate IRA accounts by December 31 of the year following the account owner's death, then all beneficiaries may be able to use their own life expectancy factors to calculate their RMD. Check with your tax advisor to see if you are eligible for this benefit. * October 31 of the year following the account owner's year of death. Important if you are the trustee of a trust named as IRA beneficiary. The IRS mandates that trustees provide the fiduciary with a copy of the trust document or a summary list of the trust's beneficiaries and conditions by this date. If this requirement is not met, or if the trust failed to meet certain other IRS requirements, it is not considered a qualifying trust eligible for more favorable RMD calculations, usually based on the life-expectancy of the oldest trust beneficiary. * Within nine months after the original account owner's death. If you are planning to disclaim the assets, your written disclaimer generally must be received no later than nine months after the date on which you become entitled to the assets, according to IRS regulations.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://personal.vanguard.com/us/accounttypes/retirement/ATSIRAInheritDeadlinesNSContent.jsp| title=IRA Inheriting Deadlines| publisher=Vanguard}}{{dead link}}</ref>
==Federal estate tax deduction== {{Quote |quote = '''<u>Federal Estate Tax on Income in Respect of a Decedent'''.</u> "This is becoming an increasingly important deduction as more and more taxpayers inherit money in company retirement plans or traditional IRAs. Such amounts are considered "income in respect of a decedent" because the decedent had a right to the income at the time of death, but the income is not included on the person's final tax return. Instead, the beneficiary is taxed on the amounts. You might also deserve a deduction, though, if the decedent's estate was large enough to pay federal estate taxes. Say, for example, that you inherit a $50,000 IRA which, because it was included in your mother's taxable estate, boosted the estate tax bill by $20,500. Although you have to pay tax as you pull money out of the IRA, you also get a deduction for that $20,500. If you pull the full $50,000 out at once, you'd get the full deduction. If you pull it out equally over two years, you'd deduct $10,250 each year. This miscellaneous deduction is not subject to the 2% limit but it is up to you to know the rules to take advantage of them." |source = -- ''[http://turbotax.intuit.com/tax-tools/maximize_tax_deductions/article Tax Tips From TurboTax]''{{dead link}} }} A beneficiary may be able to claim a deduction for estate tax resulting from certain distributions from a traditional IRA. The beneficiary can deduct the estate tax paid on any part of a distribution that is [[Income in respect of a decedent|income in respect of a decedent]] (IRD). They can take the deduction for the tax year the income is reported. The deduction is taken by the beneficiary receiving the IRD, not the beneficiary who pays the estate tax.
{| class="wikitable" | <u>Example</u><br> Jack dies in 2002 with an estate of $3 million. He leaves his $1 million IRA (which is entirely IRD) to his daughters Jill and Holly. He leaves his $2 million probate estate (which is not IRD) to his son Alex. Alex pays the federal estate tax of $897,500. The [section 691(c) IRD] deduction goes equally to Jill and Holly because they received the IRD, even though Alex is the one who paid the estate tax.{{sfn|Choate|2006|p=125}} |}
Any taxable part of a distribution that is not income in respect of a decedent is a payment the beneficiary must include in income. However, the beneficiary cannot take any estate tax deduction for this part.
A surviving spouse can roll over the distribution to another traditional IRA and avoid including it in income for the year received.
==Inherited IRA with a basis== When an IRA owner passes with IRA basis documented on [https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-form-8606 Form 8606], the remaining basis is inherited by the beneficiary in proportion to the beneficiary interests.<ref>From forum member Alan S. Also see: {{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b/| title=Publication 590-B| publisher=IRS}} (IRA with basis)</ref>
If the beneficiary is a surviving spouse who rolls the IRA over to their own name or defaults to ownership by perhaps missing an RMD, the inherited basis is added to any basis the surviving spouse may have in their own IRA. The surviving spouse would then file their own 8606 which would result in their RMDs or other distributions being partially tax free.
If the inherited IRA is maintained in inherited form, any basis in the Inherited IRA would have to be kept separate from any basis the surviving spouse has in their own IRA by filing an 8606 for each labeled "owned IRA" or "Inherited IRA". If the surviving spouse does not have any basis in their own IRAs, it could be advantageous to keep the deceased's IRA with a basis in an Inherited IRA and withdraw from that instead of from their own IRA if money is needed before RMDs start in their own IRA. Withdrawing from an Inherited IRA before you turn 59 1/2 will also avoid any early withdrawal penalties.

{{US|reason=irrelevant}} If you made a contribution to a [[Roth IRA]] or [[Traditional IRA |traditional IRA]], you can switch the type of IRA by using an '''{{PAGENAME}}'''{{cite web|url=https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590a/|title=Publication 590-A, Contributions to Individual Retirement Arrangements (IRAs)| publisher=IRS| accessdate=May 14, 2024}} up to October 15 of the year after you made the original contribution. This treats the contribution as if it was made to the other type of IRA in the first place. This is useful for correcting a contribution that you later discovered you were not allowed to make, or which you put into the wrong kind of IRA. ==Timing of recharacterization== Where you made an excess Roth contribution in one year, for example in 2016, you can recharacterize to a traditional IRA up to October 15, 2017, the six-month extension period for filing 2016 returns. In this case, the contribution to the traditional IRA can be converted to Roth as soon as the day following the recharacterization. ==How to recharacterize== To recharacterize, notify the custodian of the IRA (Vanguard, for example) which transaction you want to recharacterize. They will adjust the amount recharacterized to account for any earnings or losses on the IRA since the contribution; your custodian computes the earnings for you and transfers the proper amount to the other type of IRA. However, for tax purposes, it is treated as if you contributed the original amount. For example, if you contributed $5,000 to a Roth IRA, the Roth IRA declined in value to $4,000, and you recharacterize the contribution as a Traditional IRA contribution and are eligible for a deduction, you may deduct $5,000 as an IRA contribution for the year. If you filed your tax return by April 15 of the year following the contribution (or applied for an extension at the time), you may recharacterize until October 15 of that year. If you recharacterize after April 15, write "Filed pursuant to section 301.9100-2" on your amended return. The recharacterization may change your taxes for the year of the original contribution, even if you recharacterized in the following year. If you have already filed a tax return for the year of the contribution, you must file an amended return. If you recharacterized a Roth IRA contribution as a deductible IRA contribution, you will receive a refund. If you recharacterized a deductible IRA contribution as a Roth IRA contribution, you will owe extra tax. If you recharacterized a non-deductible IRA to a Roth IRA or vice versa, your tax owed will not change, but you still need to amend the return to correct your IRS [https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-form-8606 Form 8606]. (In this case, you can mail Form 8606 by itself, because there was no change to the taxes owed.) Following the [https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/i8606.pdf instructions for Form 8606], attach a statement to your return explaining any recharacterization. ==How to save taxes by recharacterizing== ===Changing type of IRA contribution=== If you contributed to a deductible IRA and its value rose, you can benefit by recharacterizing rather than converting directly to a Roth. If you contributed to a Roth IRA and its value fell, you can benefit by recharacterizing if you are eligible for a traditional IRA. This is still allowed under the 2018 tax law. {| class="wikitable" width="100%" | Example
You contributed $5,000 to a deductible Traditional IRA in March 2019, and expected to reduce your taxes by $1,100 because you were in a 22% tax bracket. In January 2020, with the Traditional IRA now worth $7,000, you decide that a Roth IRA would have been better. If you convert the Traditional IRA to a Roth, you would get an $1,100 tax reduction for 2019 but owe $1,540 on the conversion for 2020. But if you recharacterize the 2019 contribution as a Roth contribution, you save $440 in taxes. |} {| class="wikitable" width="100%" | Example
You contributed $5,000 to a Roth IRA in April 2019 even though you were eligible for a deductible IRA. In October 2020, your Roth has lost 40% of its value. You recharacterize the contribution, then worth $3,000, as a Traditional IRA contribution, filing an amended return, and receive an $1,100 refund because you are in a 22% tax bracket. You wait until January 2021 in order to postpone taxes for another year, then convert the Traditional IRA, which is still worth $3,000, back to a Roth IRA; you will owe $660 in taxes for 2021 on the conversion, saving $440 in taxes. |} ===Different tax brackets=== If you can undo a taxable contribution and redo it in a year in which you are in a lower tax bracket, you may benefit even if the market does not move. {| class="wikitable" width="100%" | Example
You contributed $5,000 to a Roth in 2018, when you were in the 24% bracket. When doing your taxes in February 2019, you learn that your income was too high to contribute to a Roth. You expect little income in 2019 and decide to pay the taxes at your lower 10% rate instead. Because you did not have access to an employer retirement plan in 2018, you recharacterize the contribution to a traditional IRA and take a deduction on your 2018 tax return, saving $1,200 in taxes. In February 2019, the traditional IRA is worth $5,300 so you then convert it back to the Roth a few days later and pay $530 on the conversion. You saved $670 in taxes. |} ==Missing the deadline== The IRS will consider relief for taxpayers who belatedly discover that they are ineligible for making a contribution, especially when these are errors made in good faith, and are reported prior to the IRS uncovering the error (under Reg.301.9100-1).{{cite web| url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/26/301.9100-1| title=26 CFR 301.9100-1 - Extensions of time to make elections| publisher=Legal Information Institute, Cornell University Law School}} Furthermore, both the Congress and the IRS sometimes grant extensions for disaster relief for victims of disasters.{{cite book| author=Natalie Choate| title=Life and Death Planning for Retirement Benefits| edition=6th| date=2006| isbn=978-0-9649440-7-7| pp=255-256}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://fairmark.com/retirement/roth-accounts/recharacterizations/ Recharacterizations], from Fairmark. *[https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b/ Publication 590-B, Distributions from Individual Retirement Arrangements (IRAs)], from the IRS. {{Retirement accounts|}} {{Managing your IRA|}} [[Category:IRAs]]

{{US}} If you '''inherit a Roth IRA''', you are called a beneficiary. A beneficiary can be any person or entity the owner chooses to receive the benefits of the IRA after they die. Careful selection of beneficiaries, timely and proper titling of inherited accounts, and awareness of distribution options can maximize the value of an inherited Roth IRA. In almost all cases, it is advantageous to name the primary and contingent beneficiaries you wish to inherit your Roth IRA. Except for a few situations, inherited Roth IRAs are subject to most of the same rules as [[Inheriting an IRA | inheriting a traditional IRA]]. The main differences for an inherited Roth IRA are:See: IRS Publication 590, [https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b#en_US_2021_publink100089630 Distributions After Owner's Death]{{broken link}} or ([https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p590b.pdf#page=36 PDF])Comments in wiki [[Talk:Inheriting a Roth IRA| Discussion tab (Inheriting a Roth IRA)]] by forum member Alan S. #The deceased owner is always treated as dying before their Required Beginning Date, because there is no Required Beginning Date for an owned Roth IRA. #Taxation rules follow those of owned Roth IRAs in that the 5 year holding period for qualification runs while the owner is alive and continues after his death. The beneficiary therefore needs to know the first year the owner made a Roth contribution. #The passage of the Secure Act in 2019 changes the RMD rules related to IRAs and 401(k)s. Among other changes, the Secure Act created several types of IRA beneficiaries (see below). In many instances, if the beneficiary does not qualify as an eligible designated beneficiary,{{cite web|url=https://www.morningstar.com/retirement/ed-slott-how-eligible-designated-beneficiaries-changed|title=How Rules on Eligible Designated Beneficiaries Changed for Inherited IRAs| author1=Christine Benz| author2=Ed Slott |publisher=Morningstar|date=May 9, 2024}} the inherited IRA or Roth must be liquidated within 10 years; this is different to the prior lifetime stretch rules. In the case of an inherited traditional IRA, the beneficiary may be subject to RMDs in years 1-9, depending on certain criteria. However, there are no RMDs associated with an inherited Roth subject to the 10 year rule.{{cite web| url=https://www.morningstar.com/retirement/faqs-about-inherited-iras | title=Be Aware of These New Rules for Inherited IRAs| author=Christine Benz| publisher=Morningstar|date=March 20, 2024}} Multiple non-spouse beneficiaries can create separate inherited Roth accounts by the end of the year following the year of death just as for non-Roth inherited IRAs. This will enable them to each use their own life expectancies for RMDs (Required Minimum Distributions), since RMDs are required for Roth beneficiaries, but not for owners. ==Types of IRA/Roth beneficiaries== The Secure Act modified the RMD rules for certain beneficiaries of inherited IRAs. IRA beneficiaries post Secure Act can now be classified into three categories:{{cite web|url=https://www.investopedia.com/not-designated-beneficiary-definition-5025735| title=Not Designated Beneficiaries|publisher=Investopedia}} 1. Eligible Designated Beneficiaries (EDB). There are specific requirements to qualify for EDB status, which entitles the individual beneficiaries to a lifetime stretch, similar to prior to the SECURE act.{{cite web|url=https://www.morningstar.com/retirement/ed-slott-how-eligible-designated-beneficiaries-changed|title=How Rules on Eligible Designated Beneficiaries Changed for Inherited IRAs| author1=Christine Benz| author2=Ed Slott |publisher=Morningstar|date=May 9, 2024}} The beneficiaries must be individuals or “see through” trusts in which the trust’s individual beneficiary qualifies as an EDB. The following are considered eligible designated beneficiaries and still qualify for a lifetime stretch: *The owner’s surviving spouse *The owner’s child who is less than 21 years of age{{cite web| url=https://irahelp.com/slottreport/age-majority-and-new-secure-act-regulations/#:~:text=The%20age%20of%20majority%20is,required%20minimum%20distribution%20(RMD).| title=AGE OF MAJORITY AND THE NEW SECURE ACT REGULATION| author1=Andy Ives| author2=Ed Slott | publisher=The Slott Report|date=March 2, 2022}} *A disabled individual *A chronically ill individual{{cite web| url=https://www.wealthmanagement.com/estate-planning/special-needs-trusts-can-help-secure-stretch-ira| title=Special Needs Trusts Can Help SECURE a 'Stretch' IRA| author1=Robert Dietz | author2=Jennifer Goode | publisher=Wealth Management|date=April 20, 2023}} *Any other individual who is not more than 10 years younger than the deceased IRA owner{{cite web| url=https://www.kitces.com/blog/secure-act-stretch-ira-401k-elimination-eligible-designated-beneficiary-retirement-accounts-taxes/| title=The (Partial) Death Of The Stretch IRA: How The SECURE Act Impacts Inherited Retirement Accounts| author=Michael Kitces| date=February 12, 2020}} 2. Non-Eligible Designated Beneficiaries - this category now must liquidate IRA holdings within a 10 year period. These beneficiaries are typically all other individuals who are not EDBs (including “see through” trusts where the individual beneficiary if the trust falls into this category ) 3. Not/Non Designated Beneficiaries - These include beneficiaries that are entities and not persons, such as an estate, a non see through trust and charities. These are typically subject to distribution from the IRA over a 5 year period.{{#tag:ref| If the estate remains the IRA beneficiary, the IRA must be distributed according to the following rules: *If the IRA owner has started taking required minimum distributions, the IRA must be distributed at least as quickly as the decedent's remaining required minimum distributions. * If the IRA owner is not taking required minimum distributions the IRA must be distributed according to the five-year rule. Under the five-year rule, the assets must be distributed by December 31 of the fifth year since the retirement account owner's death.{{sfn|Choate|2006|pp=89-90}}{{cite web| url= https://www.schwab.com/learn/story/inheriting-ira-understand-your-options | title= Inheriting an IRA? Understand Your Choices | author=Hayden Adams| publisher=Schwab|date=May 1, 2024}} |group="note"}} ==Spousal beneficiaries== {{Quote |quote = '''Spousal Inheritance of an IRA''' You will only be considered to have chosen to treat the IRA as your own if: * You are the sole beneficiary of the IRA, and * You have an unlimited right to withdraw amounts from it.{{cite book| author=Natalie Choate| title=Life and Death Planning for Retirement Benefits| edition=6th| date=2006| isbn=978-0-9649440-7-7| p=169| ref={{SfnRef|Choate|2006}}}} You will be considered to have chosen to treat the IRA as your own if: * Contributions (including rollover contributions) are made to the inherited IRA, or * You do not take the required minimum distribution for a year as a beneficiary of the IRA.{{sfn|Choate|2006|p=170}}}} If you inherit a Roth IRA from your spouse, you generally have the following three choices. You can: # Treat it as your own IRA by designating yourself as the account owner. # Treat it as your own by rolling it over into your Roth IRA. # Treat yourself as the beneficiary rather than treating the IRA as your own.{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p590.pdf| title=IRS Publication 590| publisher=IRS| p=20}}{{dead link}}. ===Treat as your own (spousal rollover)=== There are a number of clear advantages to spousal rollovers of a Roth IRA. #By using a spousal Roth rollover, the surviving spouse can avoid any requirements to withdraw funds from the account. However, you need to keep in mind that withdrawals of conversions within 5 years and before 59.5 will be subject to the 10% penalty on the taxable portion, and withdrawals of earnings will be subject to both tax and the 10% penalty. #A spousal rollover allows a surviving spouse to name primary and contingent beneficiaries to the IRA. This allows the surviving spouse, if the situation warrants, to correct any problems in the original beneficiary designations. Naming beneficiaries for the spousal IRA can provide these beneficiaries with the option of using their own life expectancies for drawing down minimum distributions from the IRA once they inherit it. If a sole spouse beneficiary opts to maintain the Roth as an inherited Roth, no RMDs are required until the year the deceased spouse would have reached their RMD age. Once that year arrives, if the surviving spouse dies, the named successor beneficiaries will have to continue the RMD schedule of that surviving spouse and will not be able to use their own life expectancies. A spouse, however, might decide to forgo a spousal rollover if they are under the age of 59 and 1/2 and have a clear need for the income from the Roth IRA. As beneficiary, the surviving spouse is required to take minimum distributions from the account. Withdrawals of earnings would be exempt from the 10% early withdrawal penalty tax.{{sfn|Choate|2006|pp=164-165}} ===As a spousal beneficiary=== A sole spousal beneficiary will inherit a fully qualified Roth if the owner first contributed at least 5 years before death. The death of the owner replaces the age 59.5 requirement for the Roth to be qualified. If the spousal beneficiary already owned their own Roth IRA, rolling the inherited one over will enable the 5 year period to be based on the older of the inherited Roth or their own Roth. The sole spousal beneficiary does not need to start RMDs as a beneficiary until the year the deceased spouse would have reached their RMD age, should they not roll it over to their own Roth IRA. Circumstances warranting a spousal beneficiary continuing the inherited Roth status are limited to cases where the Roth has earnings but the surviving spouse is not yet 59.5, and the surviving spouse needs to take a lump sum distribution. In this situation, taking it from the inherited Roth would avoid the 10% penalty on the taxable earnings, while assuming ownership would not. ==Non-spousal beneficiaries== Whereas a Roth IRA account owner is, under current regulations, not required to take distributions from a Roth IRA, a non-spousal beneficiary of a Roth IRA is required to make distributions from the account. With the passage of the SECURE Act, IRA distributions to a nonspouse must be completed within 10 years following the death of the account owner. Executors have until December 31 of the year following the death of the decedent owner to properly title and distribute the IRA to the beneficiaries. If you inherit a Roth IRA from anyone other than your deceased spouse, you cannot treat the inherited IRA as your own. This means that the following actions are not permitted: # You cannot make any contributions to the inherited Roth IRA. # You cannot roll over any amounts into or out of the inherited Roth IRA into your own Roth IRA. # Should you inherit Roth IRAs from more than one individual, the inherited Roth IRAs cannot be commingled or aggregated. Transfers between IRAs and RMD calculations must be made within each group of inherited IRAs.{{sfn|Choate|2006|p=90}} However, you can make a trustee-to-trustee transfer to an inherited Roth IRA as long as the IRA into which amounts are being moved is set up and maintained in the name of the deceased IRA owner for the benefit of you as beneficiary. {| class="wikitable" width="100%" | Example
"Harvey Schmidt (deceased April 10, 2008) Roth IRA, For the Benefit of Thomas Schmidt (beneficiary). SSN xxx-xx-xxxx." |} Multiple beneficiaries of a Roth IRA should split the IRA into separate interests so that each beneficiary can: #Select a fiduciary of choice for investing the inherited IRA; #Execute their own [[Investment policy statement |individual investment plan]] and account succession. {| class="wikitable" width="100%" | Example
Jill Scott has inherited a Roth IRA from her father, Thomas Scott, who held his Roth at Merrill Lynch. Jill has executed a trustee-to-trustee transfer of the inherited IRA to Vanguard and has invested the IRA in three Vanguard Funds: *Vanguard Total Stock Market Index *Vanguard Total International Index *Vanguard Short Term Treasury Fund She can transfer funds tax-free between each of these funds (and any other funds she opens within this inherited IRA). |} An inheritor of a Roth IRA can, and should, name primary and contingent beneficiaries to the inherited IRA. ==Estate as beneficiary or beneficiary not named== Not naming a beneficiary or naming the estate as beneficiary of a Roth will subject the estate to the 5 year rule [[#Non-spousal beneficiaries | above]] regardless of the age of the owner at death. For a traditional IRA, this is only true if the owner died before the Required Beginning Date. If you do not name beneficiaries to the Roth IRA, the Roth IRA will be inherited by the decedent's estate and will be distributed to the beneficiaries established by will or intestacy law. An estate executor can still designate an inherited Roth IRA to the beneficiaries, as long as this is completed by December 31 of the year following the decedent's death. :Here is a sample letter which estate executors can use to properly execute the transfer of the inherited Roth IRA to beneficiaries: [http://www.ataxplan.com/bulletinBoard/pdfs/FiducLetterWebVersion.pdf Fiduciary Letter Transferring Plan Account to Beneficiary] If the estate remains the Roth IRA beneficiary, the IRA must be distributed according to the five-year rule. Under the five-year rule, the assets must be distributed by December 31 of the fifth year since the retirement account owner's death.{{sfn|Choate|2006|pp=89-90}} ==Advanced beneficiary options== These beneficiary options require the services of a qualified estate planner. *Naming a revocable or testamentary trust as an IRA beneficiary;{{#tag:ref|Trusts can be named as beneficiaries of IRAs/retirement accounts, but special care is needed to make sure the trust is set up and worded correctly and also that the particular trust beneficiaries meet the applicable criteria, such as being individuals (not entities) and meeting “look through” criteria. Failure to comply with these rules may cause the trust to lose its potential 10 year (non-EDB) or lifetime (EDB) stretch distribution status, and revert to the default 5 year distribution status applicable to most entities (non-individuals). It is advisable to seek out an estate planning attorney who is experienced with setting up trusts that ultimately will hold IRAs or other retirement accounts.{{cite web| url= https://ataxplan.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/Estate_Planning_for_Retirement_Benefits_post_SECURE_and_Prop_Regs.pdf | title= Estate Planning for Retirement Benefits Under SECURE and Proposed Treasury Regulations | p=67-75| author=Natalie Choate| publisher=Ataxplan|date=September 8, 2022}}{{cite web| url= https://www.ntsa-net.org/industry-intel/marketbeat/naming-your-trust-beneficiary-ira| title= Naming Your Trust as Beneficiary of an IRA| author=NTSA| publisher=National Tax Deferred Association}}|group="note"}}{{#tag:ref|Naming a trust as beneficiary of a Roth IRA can be advantageous when compared to a traditional IRA for the following reasons: 1. Trust tax brackets are compressed compared to individual tax brackets, increasing the tax burden of any taxable income retained within the trust (In an accumulation type trust). Since Roth IRA distributions are tax free, the higher trust tax burden is avoided. 2. If the inherited Roth within the trust is subject to the 10 year rule, unlike inherited traditional IRAs, inherited Roth IRAs are not subject to RMDs in years 1-9.|group="note"}} *Disclaiming a Roth IRA ===Tax factors=== While most distributions from an inherited Roth IRA will be tax free distributions, there are circumstances in which a tax may be assessed. An inherited IRA by regulation is not subject to the 10 percent early withdrawal penalty tax (excepting Spousal rollovers, discussed later). However, it is possible for the earnings of an inherited Roth IRA to be subject to tax if withdrawn. This is due to the five year holding requirement for inherited Roth IRAs. In order for earnings to be qualified for tax free distribution, the original account owner must have held the Roth IRA for a minimum of five years. The account can be started by either contributions or conversions.{{cite web| url=https://fairmark.com/retirement/roth-accounts/roth-distributions/inherited-roth-ira/| title=Inherited Roth IRA| publisher=Fairmark| url-status=dead| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210420054220/https://fairmark.com/retirement/roth-accounts/roth-distributions/inherited-roth-ira/| archive-date=April 20, 2021}} If a Roth IRA is established by a conversion that is subsequently [[IRA recharacterization |recharacterized]] the original Roth establishment date is nullified and will be established if and when the recharacterized funds are reinvested into the Roth IRA.{{sfn|Choate|2006|p=233}} The five year threshold is met on January 1 of the anniversary year. The following table provides the five year anniversary threshold for various creation dates. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |+ Roth IRA five year holding period requirement ! First year Roth contribution ! Five year date |- | align="left"| Before 2014 || Passed requirement |- | align="left"|2015 || January 1, 2020 |- | align="left"|2016 || January 1, 2021 |- | align="left"|2017|| January 1, 2022 |- | align="left"|2018|| January 1, 2023 |- | align="left"|2019|| January 1, 2024 |} The [[Roth IRA#Distributions |ordering rules]] for Roth IRA distribution provide options for avoiding this tax on earnings. {| class="wikitable" width="100%" | Example
Amanda Parker inherits a Roth IRA from her uncle Charles. The IRA was started in 2012 and has a value of $6500 consisting of $6000 of contributions and $500 of earnings. If Amanda takes immediate distribution of the account she will receive the $6000 of contributions tax free. The $500 of earnings will not be subject to the 10% early withdrawal penalty, but because the Roth IRA fails the five year test, Amanda will have to report the $500 of Roth earnings as a taxable distribution on her tax return. Amanda can escape taxation in this instance by only withdrawing the $6000 of contributions and retaining the $500 earnings in an inherited Roth IRA. She can use the Five Year Rule to delay distribution until the five year holding period is reached. The distribution will then be tax free. |} For larger accounts with insufficient tenure (most likely converted accounts) the ordering rules usually mean that distributions will come from contributions or conversions and not from earnings until well after the Roth IRA passes the five year test. If in any year the distributions from an inherited Roth IRA are less than the required minimum distribution for the year, you may have to pay the '''Tax on excess accumulations (insufficient distributions)''', a 50% excise tax for that year on the amount not distributed as required. The tax on excess accumulations is reported on IRS [https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-form-5329 Form 5329]. Finally, for large estates, a Roth IRA may be subject to the estate tax. ==Roth 401k and Roth 403b accounts== Beginning in 2006, corporate qualified plans, such as 401k and 403b plans, were able to offer a '''designated Roth account (DRAC)''' within the plan. The distribution rules governing these plans are somewhat different from those governing individual Roth IRAs. Among the differences: #For 2024 and later years, RMDs are no longer required from designated Roth 401(k) and 403(b) accounts.{{cite web| url= https://www.irs.gov/retirement-plans/retirement-plan-and-ira-required-minimum-distributions-faqs#:~:text=Designated%20Roth%20accounts%20in%20a,required%20from%20designated%20Roth%20accounts | title= Retirement plan and IRA Required Minimum Distributions FAQs | publisher=Internal Revenue Service}} For 2023 and earlier, unlike Roth IRAs, Roth 401(k)s and 403(b)s were subject to RMDs. RMDs began the year when: (1) the owner reached RMD age, or (2) the owner retired from the employer (if the plan permits), whichever is ''later''. However, retiring employees generally had the option to roll over Roth balances into a Roth IRA, which has no RMDs, so RMDs were avoided this way.{{sfn|Choate|2006|p=261}} #The five year holding period for 401k and 403b Roth IRAs (DRACs) is applied for each particular plan held by the employee. #Ordering rules for Roth IRA distributions do not apply to DRACs. Any distribution from the account is prorated according to the proportion of account basis and earnings in the account.{{sfn|Choate|2006|p=261}} #The five year holding period for DRACs does not carryover to a Roth IRA rollover. A rollover to a first time Roth IRA begins the holding period for the rollover. A rollover into an existing Roth IRA will receive the tenure of the existing IRA.{{sfn|Choate|2006|pp=267-269}} ==Qualified distributions== Once an inherited Roth is qualified (5 years from original contribution), it is fully qualified and [https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-form-8606 Form 8606] is not required to report distributions. The gross distributions are entered only on line 15a of Form 1040. For non-qualified inherited Roth IRAs, the basis from regular contributions and conversions is prorated according to each beneficiary's percent interest. ==Notes== {{Reflist|group="note"}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590a/ Publication 590-A (2014), Contributions to Individual Retirement Arrangements (IRAs)], [http://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p590a.pdf (PDF)] *[https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b/ Publication 590-B (2014), Distributions from Individual Retirement Arrangements (IRAs)], [http://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p590b.pdf (PDF)] *[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p590.pdf#page=59 IRS Pub 590 p. 59+],{{dead link}} 2013. Superseded by 590-A and 590-B. *[https://investor.vanguard.com/accounts-plans/iras Individual retirement accounts], from Vanguard *[https://www.ecfr.gov/current/title-26/chapter-I/subchapter-A/part-1/section-1.408A-6 Code of Federal Regulations, Q&A on distributions from Roth IRAs] ===Articles=== *[https://www.investopedia.com/articles/retirement/04/070704.asp RIP: The Stretch IRA], Denise Appleby, Investopedia {{Retirement accounts}} {{Managing your IRA}} {{Estate planning|state=uncollapsed}} [[Category:IRAs]] [[Category:Stretch IRA]] [[Category:Estate planning]]
